Description: Panic disorder is a type of anxiety disorder characterized by sudden, recurrent panic attacks involving intense fear or discomfort. Symptoms include palpitations, sweating, chest pain, dizziness, and a fear of losing control. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), and lifestyle modifications.

A vocal cord polyp is a benign growth on the vocal fold, often due to vocal abuse or irritation. Symptoms include hoarseness, breathy voice, and vocal fatigue. Treatment may involve voice rest, speech therapy, and surgical removal if persistent.

Turner syndrome is a genetic condition affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome. Common features include short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, and heart or kidney abnormalities. Treatment involves growth hormone therapy, estrogen replacement, and regular health monitoring.

Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testicles fail to descend into the scrotum at birth. It may resolve spontaneously, but untreated cases increase the risk of infertility and cancer. Treatment includes hormone therapy or surgical correction (orchiopexy), typically before age 1.

Ethylene glycol poisoning occurs from ingesting antifreeze and is life-threatening. Early symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and intoxication-like effects, progressing to kidney failure, seizures, and coma. Treatment involves activated charcoal, antidotes like fomepizole or ethanol, and possibly dialysis.

Atrophic vaginitis is the thinning and inflammation of vaginal walls due to decreased estrogen, often after menopause. Symptoms include vaginal dryness, itching, burning, and painful intercourse. Treatment includes topical estrogen therapy, moisturizers, and lubricants.

A fracture of the hand involves a break in one of the hand bones, often from trauma. Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty moving fingers. Treatment includes splinting, casting, or surgery depending on the severity and location of the fracture.

Cellulitis or abscess of the mouth is a bacterial infection of soft tissues, often from dental issues. Symptoms include swelling, redness, pain, fever, and pus formation. Treatment involves antibiotics, drainage if necessary, and addressing the underlying dental cause.

Eye alignment disorders like strabismus occur when the eyes don't move in sync. Symptoms include double vision, eye strain, or a noticeable eye turn. Treatment includes corrective glasses, vision therapy, or surgical realignment of eye muscles.

Headache after a lumbar puncture is due to cerebrospinal fluid leakage, causing decreased brain cushioning. Symptoms include a headache worse when sitting/standing and relief when lying down. Treatment includes bed rest, hydration, caffeine, and sometimes a blood patch procedure.

Pyloric stenosis is a condition in infants where the pylorus muscles thicken, blocking food from entering the intestine. Symptoms include projectile vomiting, weight loss, and dehydration. Treatment is surgical (pyloromyotomy) to relieve the blockage.

Salivary gland disorders include infections, stones, or tumors affecting saliva production. Symptoms may include swelling, pain while eating, dry mouth, or pus discharge. Treatment depends on the cause—hydration, massage, antibiotics, or surgery may be needed.

Osteochondrosis is a condition affecting bone growth in children, often involving joints like the knees or hips. It causes joint pain, stiffness, and swelling. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, pain relievers, and occasionally surgery for severe cases.

Knee injuries can involve ligaments, cartilage, bones, or tendons. Symptoms include pain, swelling, instability, or difficulty walking. Treatment ranges from rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) to physical therapy, bracing, or surgery depending on severity.

Metabolic disorders are a group of conditions that disrupt normal metabolism, often due to enzyme deficiencies or hormonal imbalances. Symptoms vary by condition but may include fatigue, growth issues, or organ damage. Treatment depends on the disorder and may include dietary management, supplements, or hormone therapy.

Vaginitis is inflammation of the vagina due to infection, irritants, or hormonal changes. Symptoms include itching, discharge, odor, and discomfort during urination or sex. Treatment varies by cause: antifungals for yeast, antibiotics for bacterial vaginosis, or estrogen creams for atrophic vaginitis.

Sick sinus syndrome is a group of heart rhythm disorders due to malfunction of the sinus node. Symptoms include fatigue, dizziness, palpitations, or fainting. Treatment often involves a pacemaker to regulate heart rhythm, especially in symptomatic cases.

Tinnitus is the perception of ringing or buzzing in the ears without an external source. When the cause is unknown, it may be linked to age, noise exposure, or other underlying issues. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms through sound therapy, hearing aids, or medications for associated anxiety.

Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often due to increased intraocular pressure. Symptoms may include vision loss starting with peripheral vision and eye pain in acute cases. Treatment includes eye drops to reduce pressure, laser therapy, or surgery to prevent vision loss.

Eating disorders are mental health conditions involving unhealthy eating habits, such as anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge-eating disorder. Symptoms include extreme food restriction, purging, obsession with weight, and emotional distress. Treatment includes psychotherapy (especially CBT), nutritional counseling, and medical monitoring.

A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, often called a mini-stroke. Symptoms mimic a stroke—sudden weakness, speech difficulty, or vision changes—but resolve within 24 hours. Treatment includes antiplatelet medications, lifestyle changes, and managing risk factors to prevent a future stroke.

Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the kidney. Symptoms include fever, flank pain, painful urination, and nausea. It is treated with antibiotics, hydration, and sometimes hospitalization in severe cases.

Rotator cuff injuries involve damage to the shoulder muscles/tendons due to overuse or trauma. Symptoms include shoulder pain, weakness, and limited range of motion. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medications, corticosteroid injections, or surgery in severe cases.

Chronic pain disorder involves long-lasting pain not explained by underlying tissue damage. Symptoms include persistent pain, fatigue, and emotional distress. Treatment includes physical therapy, medications (e.g., antidepressants or pain relievers), psychological counseling, and sometimes interdisciplinary pain management programs.

Problems during pregnancy can include conditions like gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, or infections. Symptoms vary based on the issue—high blood pressure, swelling, or abnormal fetal growth. Treatment includes close monitoring, medication, dietary adjustments, or early delivery if necessary.

Liver cancer occurs when malignant cells form in the tissues of the liver. Symptoms include weight loss, abdominal pain, jaundice, and fatigue. Treatment may include surgical resection, liver transplant, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or ablation.

Atelectasis is the partial or complete collapse of a lung or lobe, reducing oxygen exchange. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest discomfort. Treatment includes breathing exercises, chest physiotherapy, addressing the underlying cause, and sometimes bronchoscopy.

Hand injuries can involve fractures, dislocations, lacerations, or tendon damage. Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and limited movement. Treatment depends on the type and severity, including rest, immobilization, physical therapy, or surgery.

Choledocholithiasis is the presence of gallstones in the bile duct, which can block bile flow. Symptoms include jaundice, right upper abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. Treatment includes endoscopic removal (ERCP), surgery, and sometimes antibiotics if infection is present.

Injury to the hip may involve fractures, dislocations, or soft tissue damage. Symptoms include hip pain, difficulty walking, swelling, and limited motion. Treatment ranges from rest and physiotherapy to surgical repair or hip replacement.

Cirrhosis is the irreversible scarring of the liver due to long-term damage from alcohol use, hepatitis, or fatty liver disease. Symptoms include fatigue, jaundice, swelling, and easy bruising. Treatment includes managing the cause, avoiding alcohol, medications, and liver transplant in advanced cases.

A thoracic aortic aneurysm is a bulging in the wall of the aorta in the chest. It may be asymptomatic or cause chest/back pain, coughing, or hoarseness. Treatment includes blood pressure control, regular imaging, and surgical repair for large or symptomatic aneurysms.

A subdural hemorrhage is bleeding between the brain surface and its outer covering, usually from head trauma. Symptoms include headache, confusion, weakness, and loss of consciousness. Treatment ranges from monitoring to surgical drainage depending on severity.

Diabetic retinopathy is a diabetes complication causing damage to the blood vessels of the retina. Symptoms include blurred vision, floaters, or vision loss. Treatment includes blood sugar control, laser therapy, anti-VEGF injections, or vitrectomy in advanced cases.

Fibromyalgia is a chronic disorder causing widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and cognitive issues ("fibro fog"). Symptoms also include sleep disturbances and mood problems. Treatment includes exercise, cognitive behavioral therapy, pain relievers, and medications like duloxetine or pregabalin.

Ischemia of the bowel occurs when blood flow to the intestines is reduced, leading to tissue damage. Symptoms include sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and bloody stools. Treatment includes fluid resuscitation, antibiotics, surgery to remove dead tissue, and treating the underlying cause.

Fetal alcohol syndrome results from alcohol consumption during pregnancy, causing developmental abnormalities. Symptoms include facial deformities, growth deficiencies, learning disabilities, and behavioral problems. There is no cure; treatment focuses on educational support and behavioral therapy.

Peritonitis is inflammation of the peritoneum, often due to infection or perforation. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and bloating. Treatment requires hospitalization, antibiotics, and possibly surgery to treat the source of infection.

Abdominal injuries can result from blunt or penetrating trauma. Symptoms include abdominal pain, bruising, internal bleeding, or organ damage. Treatment depends on the injury's nature and severity and may include observation, surgery, or supportive care.

Acute pancreatitis is sudden inflammation of the pancreas, often due to gallstones or alcohol use. Symptoms include severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and a tender abdomen. Treatment includes fasting, IV fluids, pain management, and addressing the underlying cause such as gallstone removal or alcohol cessation.

Thrombophlebitis is inflammation of a vein due to a blood clot, commonly in the legs. Symptoms include redness, warmth, swelling, and tenderness over the affected vein. Treatment includes compression stockings, anti-inflammatory medications, and anticoagulants in cases of deep vein involvement.

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Symptoms can worsen with triggers like allergens or cold air. Treatment includes inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators, and avoiding triggers.

This condition occurs when an object is lodged inside the vaginal canal, often in children or due to tampon use. Symptoms may include foul-smelling discharge, bleeding, or pain. Treatment involves careful removal, sometimes under sedation, and treating any resulting infection.

Restless leg syndrome is a neurological condition causing an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, especially at night. Symptoms include tingling or crawling sensations that improve with movement. Treatment includes iron supplementation (if deficient), dopamine agonists, and lifestyle changes.

Emphysema is a chronic lung condition involving damage to the alveoli, leading to breathlessness and reduced oxygen exchange. Common symptoms are chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Treatment includes smoking cessation, bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and pulmonary rehabilitation.

Cysticercosis is an infection caused by the larval stage of the pork tapeworm, often affecting the brain or muscles. Symptoms vary but may include seizures, headaches, or lumps under the skin. Treatment includes antiparasitic drugs like albendazole, corticosteroids, and in some cases, surgery.

Induced abortion is the medical or surgical termination of pregnancy. Symptoms post-procedure may include bleeding, cramping, and hormonal changes. Treatment involves safe abortion practices, pain management, and follow-up care to ensure no complications.

Teething syndrome refers to the process in infants when teeth break through the gums. Symptoms include drooling, irritability, gum swelling, and a tendency to chew on objects. Treatment includes gentle gum massage, teething toys, and occasionally acetaminophen for pain relief.

Infectious gastroenteritis is inflammation of the stomach and intestines caused by bacteria, viruses, or parasites. Symptoms include diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and fever. Treatment includes hydration, rest, and in some cases, antibiotics or antiparasitic medications.

Acute sinusitis is the inflammation of the sinuses usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection. Symptoms include facial pain, nasal congestion, headache, and thick nasal discharge. Treatment includes nasal decongestants, saline sprays, and antibiotics if bacterial.

This refers to mental health conditions caused by the abuse of drugs or alcohol, including depression, anxiety, or psychosis. Symptoms vary by substance but can include mood swings, hallucinations, and cognitive impairment. Treatment includes detoxification, psychotherapy, and substance use rehabilitation.

Postpartum depression is a mood disorder affecting women after childbirth. Symptoms include sadness, anxiety, fatigue, and difficulty bonding with the baby. Treatment includes counseling, support groups, and antidepressant medications when necessary.

Coronary atherosclerosis is the buildup of plaque in the arteries of the heart, reducing blood flow. Symptoms can include chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, cholesterol-lowering medications, and potentially procedures like angioplasty or bypass surgery.

Spondylitis refers to inflammation of the vertebrae, commonly seen in conditions like ankylosing spondylitis. Symptoms include back pain, stiffness, and reduced spinal mobility. Treatment includes NSAIDs, physical therapy, and biologic medications in autoimmune types.

A pituitary adenoma is a usually benign tumor of the pituitary gland. Symptoms include vision changes, hormone imbalances, and headaches. Treatment includes surgery, medications to shrink the tumor or balance hormones, and occasionally radiation.

Uterine fibroids are noncancerous growths of the uterus that often appear during childbearing years. Symptoms may include heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and frequent urination. Treatment options include hormonal therapy, uterine artery embolization, or surgical removal.

This refers to abnormal uterine bleeding without a clear cause, often not related to menstruation. Symptoms include irregular spotting or bleeding. Treatment may involve hormonal regulation with birth control or further evaluation to exclude structural causes.

A chalazion is a blocked oil gland in the eyelid that causes a painless lump. Symptoms include localized swelling, redness, and sometimes blurred vision. Treatment includes warm compresses, gentle massage, and, in resistant cases, surgical drainage.

Ovarian torsion is the twisting of the ovary, cutting off its blood supply. Symptoms include sudden, severe lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment is emergency surgery to untwist or remove the ovary to prevent tissue death.

Disease: retinopathy due to high blood pressure
Description: Retinopathy due to high blood pressure (hypertensive retinopathy) is damage to the retina from prolonged high blood pressure. Symptoms may include blurry vision, double vision, or vision loss. Treatment involves controlling blood pressure with medications, lifestyle changes, and regular eye exams.

Vaginal yeast infection is caused by an overgrowth of Candida fungus in the vaginal area. Symptoms include itching, burning, thick white discharge, and irritation. Treatment includes antifungal creams, suppositories, or oral medications like fluconazole.

Mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bone behind the ear, often following untreated ear infections. Symptoms include ear pain, swelling behind the ear, fever, and drainage. Treatment includes antibiotics and, in severe cases, surgical drainage or mastoidectomy.

Lung contusion is bruising of lung tissue due to trauma, leading to bleeding and swelling. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, coughing up blood, and low oxygen levels. Treatment includes oxygen therapy, pain control, and supportive care; severe cases may need ventilation.

HOCM is a genetic condition where the heart muscle thickens, obstructing blood flow. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, fainting, and palpitations. Treatment includes beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and in some cases, surgical interventions like septal myectomy or ICD placement.

An ingrown toenail occurs when the edge of a nail grows into the surrounding skin, causing pain, redness, swelling, and infection. Treatment includes warm soaks, proper nail trimming, antibiotics if infected, and sometimes surgical removal of the nail edge.

Pulmonary eosinophilia is a condition where eosinophils (a type of white blood cell) accumulate in the lungs due to infections, allergens, or autoimmune diseases. Symptoms include cough, fever, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Treatment depends on the cause and may involve corticosteroids or antiparasitic drugs.

Corneal disorders include a range of conditions affecting the transparent front layer of the eye, such as infections, injuries, or degenerations. Symptoms include eye pain, redness, blurred vision, and light sensitivity. Treatment varies and may involve eye drops, antibiotics, or surgery like corneal transplant.

Disease: foreign body in the gastrointestinal tract
Description: This occurs when a non-food object is ingested and becomes lodged in the digestive tract. Symptoms include pain, vomiting, difficulty swallowing, or bleeding. Treatment often involves endoscopic removal; surgery may be needed in complicated cases.

Endophthalmitis is a severe inflammation of the interior of the eye, usually due to infection after surgery or trauma. Symptoms include pain, decreased vision, swelling, and redness. It is a medical emergency and requires prompt antibiotic injections or surgery.

Intestinal malabsorption is the inability to absorb nutrients properly due to diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s, or infections. Symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, bloating, and fatigue. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and may involve dietary changes, enzyme supplements, or medications.

Viral warts are skin growths caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). They are commonly found on hands, feet, or genital areas. Symptoms include raised, rough bumps. Treatment includes topical salicylic acid, cryotherapy, laser therapy, or immune-modulating treatments.

Hyperhidrosis is excessive sweating not related to heat or exercise, usually affecting hands, feet, armpits, or face. It can cause embarrassment and skin infections. Treatment includes antiperspirants, Botox injections, medications, and in severe cases, surgery to remove sweat glands.

A stroke occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, leading to brain damage. Symptoms include sudden weakness, slurred speech, facial drooping, and vision changes. Treatment includes clot-busting drugs, surgery, and rehabilitation; prevention involves controlling risk factors like hypertension.

A pilonidal cyst is a fluid-filled sac near the tailbone, often containing hair and skin debris. Symptoms include pain, redness, and pus drainage. Treatment includes drainage, antibiotics for infection, and surgical removal for recurrent cases.

A crushing injury occurs when a body part is subjected to a high degree of force or pressure. Symptoms include severe pain, swelling, bruising, and potential tissue death. Treatment may involve emergency surgery, fluids, pain management, and preventing complications like compartment syndrome.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a buildup of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain’s ventricles with normal pressure. Symptoms include walking difficulties, dementia-like symptoms, and urinary incontinence. Treatment typically involves surgical placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt to drain fluid.

Alopecia is hair loss from the scalp or other parts of the body. It can be caused by autoimmune diseases, genetics, or stress. Symptoms include patchy or total hair loss. Treatment includes topical minoxidil, corticosteroids, or immunotherapy, depending on the type.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the thyroid, leading to hypothyroidism. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Treatment involves lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

Flat feet is a condition where the arches of the feet collapse, leading to the entire sole touching the ground. Symptoms include foot pain, swelling, and difficulty standing for long periods. Treatment includes arch supports, physical therapy, and in severe cases, corrective surgery.

Nonalcoholic liver disease (NASH) is a condition where fat builds up in the liver without alcohol use, leading to inflammation and liver damage. Symptoms may be absent or include fatigue and right upper abdominal pain. Treatment involves weight loss, a healthy diet, exercise, and controlling conditions like diabetes and high cholesterol.

Hemarthrosis is bleeding into a joint cavity, often due to trauma, bleeding disorders like hemophilia, or anticoagulant use. Symptoms include joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and limited movement. Treatment involves rest, ice, aspiration of blood, pain control, and treating underlying bleeding disorders.

Pelvic organ prolapse occurs when pelvic organs like the bladder or uterus drop into or outside the vaginal canal due to weak pelvic muscles. Symptoms include pressure, urinary incontinence, or discomfort during sex. Treatment includes pelvic floor exercises, pessaries, or surgical repair.

A fracture of the arm is a break in one of the bones of the upper limb, often caused by trauma or falls. Symptoms include pain, swelling, deformity, and inability to move the arm. Treatment includes immobilization with a cast or splint, pain relief, and sometimes surgical fixation.

Coagulation disorders involve problems with blood clotting, leading to excessive bleeding or clot formation. Symptoms include frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding, or prolonged bleeding after injury. Treatment depends on the cause and may include clotting factor replacement, anticoagulants, or other medications.

Intracranial hemorrhage is bleeding inside the skull, usually due to trauma, aneurysm, or high blood pressure. Symptoms include headache, vomiting, confusion, weakness, and loss of consciousness. It is a medical emergency requiring immediate imaging and often surgery or medications to reduce brain pressure.

Hyperkalemia is a high level of potassium in the blood, often caused by kidney failure, medications, or tissue damage. Symptoms may include muscle weakness, fatigue, palpitations, or arrhythmias. Treatment includes medications like diuretics, calcium gluconate, insulin with glucose, or dialysis.

Cornea infection (keratitis) is inflammation of the cornea caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. Symptoms include eye redness, pain, tearing, sensitivity to light, and blurred vision. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotic, antiviral, or antifungal eye drops.

A lung abscess is a localized infection in the lung tissue causing pus-filled cavities, often due to bacterial infection. Symptoms include fever, cough with foul-smelling sputum, chest pain, and fatigue. Treatment involves antibiotics and sometimes drainage or surgery if the abscess is large or persistent.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness found in tropical areas. Symptoms include high fever, severe headache, joint and muscle pain, rash, and bleeding. There is no specific treatment, but supportive care with fluids and pain relief is essential. Severe cases may require hospitalization.

Chronic sinusitis is long-term inflammation of the sinuses, often due to infection, allergies, or nasal polyps. Symptoms include nasal congestion, facial pain, postnasal drip, and reduced sense of smell. Treatment includes nasal corticosteroids, saline rinses, antibiotics if bacterial, and surgery in severe cases.

Cholesteatoma is an abnormal skin growth in the middle ear that can erode nearby structures. Symptoms include hearing loss, ear discharge, and fullness or pain. Treatment typically involves surgical removal to prevent complications like infection or damage to hearing and balance structures.

Volvulus is a twisting of the intestine that can block blood flow and cause obstruction. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain, bloating, vomiting, and constipation. It is a surgical emergency requiring untwisting of the bowel and sometimes resection if tissue is necrotic.

Injuries to the finger include cuts, fractures, sprains, or dislocations, usually due to trauma. Symptoms vary based on injury type but often include pain, swelling, bruising, and limited movement. Treatment includes cleaning wounds, splinting, pain control, and sometimes surgery.

This occurs when pain-relief medications like acetaminophen or NSAIDs are taken in excessive amounts. Symptoms depend on the drug but may include nausea, confusion, liver or kidney failure, and coma. Treatment involves activated charcoal, antidotes like N-acetylcysteine, and supportive care.

Atrial fibrillation is an irregular and often rapid heart rhythm that can cause poor blood flow. Symptoms include palpitations, fatigue, shortness of breath, and dizziness. Treatment includes medications for rate/rhythm control, blood thinners to prevent clots, and sometimes cardioversion or ablation.

Pinworm infection is a parasitic disease caused by *Enterobius vermicularis*, common in children. Symptoms include anal itching, restlessness, and disturbed sleep. Treatment includes antiparasitic medications like mebendazole or albendazole and hygiene measures to prevent reinfection.

Urethral valves are congenital abnormal flaps in the male urethra that obstruct urine flow. Symptoms may include urinary retention, poor stream, and recurrent infections. Diagnosis is through imaging and treatment often involves endoscopic valve ablation or surgery.

An open wound of the neck can result from trauma or surgery and carries risks due to vital structures nearby. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and visible tissue damage. Treatment involves wound cleaning, closure, antibiotics, and monitoring for complications like infection or airway obstruction.

Achalasia is a rare esophageal disorder where the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax, causing difficulty swallowing. Symptoms include regurgitation, chest pain, and weight loss. Treatment includes pneumatic dilation, medications, Botox injections, or surgical procedures like Heller myotomy.

Conductive hearing loss occurs when sound waves cannot efficiently pass through the outer or middle ear. It may be caused by earwax buildup, ear infections, fluid in the middle ear, or structural abnormalities. Symptoms include muffled hearing and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Treatment depends on the cause and may involve earwax removal, antibiotics for infections, surgical repair, or hearing aids.

An abdominal hernia occurs when an internal organ or tissue pushes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall. Symptoms may include a visible bulge, pain, or discomfort, especially during physical activity. Treatment often involves surgical repair to prevent complications such as strangulation of the herniated tissue.

Cerebral palsy is a group of neurological disorders that affect movement, muscle tone, and posture, caused by brain damage during development. Symptoms include muscle stiffness, coordination issues, and developmental delays. Treatment includes physical and occupational therapy, medications for muscle control, and sometimes surgery.

Marijuana abuse refers to the excessive or harmful use of cannabis, leading to dependence or negative impact on daily life. Symptoms include impaired memory, altered judgment, anxiety, and decreased motivation. Treatment may include counseling, behavioral therapy, and support groups.

Cryptococcosis is a fungal infection caused by *Cryptococcus* species, commonly affecting the lungs or central nervous system, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Symptoms include cough, fever, headache, and confusion. Treatment involves antifungal medications like amphotericin B and fluconazole.

Obesity is a condition characterized by excessive body fat, increasing the risk of diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, and certain cancers. Symptoms include high BMI and physical limitations. Treatment involves dietary changes, exercise, behavioral therapy, medications, and in some cases, bariatric surgery.

Indigestion, or dyspepsia, refers to discomfort or pain in the upper abdomen, often related to eating. Symptoms include bloating, nausea, burping, and a burning sensation. Treatment includes lifestyle modifications, antacids, H2 blockers, and proton pump inhibitors.

Bursitis is inflammation of the bursa, small fluid-filled sacs that cushion bones, tendons, and muscles. Commonly affects shoulders, elbows, or hips. Symptoms include joint pain, swelling, and limited movement. Treatment includes rest, ice, anti-inflammatory medications, and sometimes corticosteroid injections.

Esophageal cancer involves malignant growth in the esophagus. Symptoms include difficulty swallowing, weight loss, chest pain, and hoarseness. Treatment depends on the stage and may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or targeted therapy.

Pulmonary congestion refers to fluid accumulation in the lungs, often due to heart failure. Symptoms include shortness of breath, coughing, and wheezing. Treatment involves diuretics, oxygen therapy, and addressing the underlying heart condition.

Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder in children causing persistent joint inflammation. Symptoms include joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and fatigue. Treatment involves NSAIDs, DMARDs, corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

Actinic keratosis is a rough, scaly patch on the skin caused by long-term sun exposure and may develop into skin cancer. Symptoms include small, dry, or crusty patches on sun-exposed areas. Treatment includes cryotherapy, topical medications, and laser therapy.

Acute otitis media is a sudden infection of the middle ear, common in children. Symptoms include ear pain, fever, irritability, and hearing loss. Treatment includes pain relievers, antibiotics if bacterial, and sometimes ear tubes for recurrent cases.

Astigmatism is a common vision condition caused by an irregularly shaped cornea or lens. Symptoms include blurry or distorted vision, eye strain, and headaches. Treatment includes corrective lenses or refractive surgery.

Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder causing noncancerous tumors in various organs, especially the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart. Symptoms include seizures, developmental delay, and skin abnormalities. Treatment focuses on symptom management with medications, surgery, or supportive therapies.

Empyema is the collection of pus in the pleural cavity, often due to pneumonia or lung infection. Symptoms include chest pain, cough, fever, and shortness of breath. Treatment involves antibiotics and drainage of the pleural space.

Presbyacusis is age-related hearing loss due to gradual degeneration of inner ear structures. Symptoms include difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds and understanding speech in noisy environments. Treatment includes hearing aids and communication strategies.

Neonatal jaundice is yellowing of a newborn's skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels. It is common and usually harmless. Symptoms include yellow discoloration, sleepiness, and poor feeding. Treatment may include phototherapy or exchange transfusion in severe cases.

COPD is a group of progressive lung diseases, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis. Symptoms include chronic cough, wheezing, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment includes smoking cessation, bronchodilators, steroids, pulmonary rehab, and oxygen therapy.

Elbow dislocation occurs when the bones of the forearm move out of alignment with the humerus. Symptoms include severe pain, deformity, swelling, and inability to move the arm. Treatment involves reduction (repositioning), immobilization, and physical therapy.

Spondylosis is age-related degeneration of the spinal discs and joints, often affecting the neck or lower back. Symptoms include pain, stiffness, and sometimes nerve compression. Treatment includes physical therapy, pain medications, and occasionally surgery.

Herpangina is a viral illness typically in children, caused by coxsackievirus. Symptoms include fever, sore throat, and small blisters or ulcers in the mouth and throat. Treatment is supportive with hydration and pain relief.

Shoulder injuries can include strains, dislocations, fractures, or rotator cuff tears. Symptoms include pain, limited mobility, and swelling. Treatment depends on the type and may include rest, ice, physical therapy, or surgery.

Overdose or adverse reaction to antidepressants can lead to symptoms like confusion, seizures, irregular heartbeat, and coma. Common in tricyclic and SSRI overdose. Treatment includes activated charcoal, supportive care, and in severe cases, ICU monitoring or antidotes.

Infection in an open wound occurs when bacteria enter broken skin. Symptoms include redness, warmth, pus, and increased pain. Treatment includes wound cleaning, antibiotics, and sometimes surgical debridement.

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot in a deep vein, usually in the legs. Symptoms include swelling, pain, redness, and warmth in the affected leg. It can lead to pulmonary embolism if the clot travels to the lungs. Treatment includes anticoagulant medications, compression stockings, and in severe cases, thrombolysis or surgical removal.

Protein deficiency occurs when the body doesn't get enough protein, leading to muscle wasting, weakened immunity, and poor wound healing. Symptoms include fatigue, hair thinning, edema, and infections. Treatment involves dietary adjustments to include protein-rich foods like meat, dairy, legumes, and supplements if needed.

Myoclonus is a sudden, involuntary muscle jerk. It can be benign or associated with conditions like epilepsy or metabolic disorders. Symptoms include twitching or jerking of muscles, especially at rest or during sleep. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antiepileptic medications or muscle relaxants.

A bone spur of the calcaneus (heel bone) is a bony outgrowth that can cause heel pain and discomfort, especially while walking. It is often associated with plantar fasciitis. Symptoms include sharp pain under the heel. Treatment includes rest, orthotic devices, physical therapy, and anti-inflammatory medications; surgery may be considered in severe cases.

Von Willebrand disease is a genetic bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, affecting blood clotting. Symptoms include frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding. Treatment includes desmopressin, clotting factor concentrates, and antifibrinolytic medications.

An open wound of the back involves a break in the skin that may expose underlying tissues. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and risk of infection. Treatment includes cleaning the wound, applying dressings, antibiotics if infected, and tetanus vaccination if needed.

Heart block is a condition where the electrical signals in the heart are delayed or blocked, leading to slow or irregular heartbeats. Symptoms may include dizziness, fatigue, fainting, and palpitations. Treatment depends on severity and may include a pacemaker to regulate heartbeat.

Colonic polyps are growths on the inner lining of the colon that can be benign or precancerous. Symptoms are usually absent but can include rectal bleeding or changes in bowel habits. Treatment involves removal during colonoscopy and monitoring for recurrence.

Magnesium deficiency can result from poor dietary intake, gastrointestinal losses, or certain medications. Symptoms include muscle cramps, weakness, fatigue, and abnormal heart rhythms. Treatment includes magnesium-rich foods, oral supplements, or intravenous magnesium in severe cases.

Female infertility of unknown cause is diagnosed when no specific medical reason for infertility is identified. Symptoms include the inability to conceive after one year of trying. Treatment options include lifestyle changes, ovulation induction, intrauterine insemination (IUI), or in vitro fertilization (IVF).

Pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium, the sac around the heart. Symptoms include sharp chest pain, fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. Treatment includes anti-inflammatory drugs, colchicine, and sometimes corticosteroids; severe cases may require drainage if fluid accumulates.

ADHD is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsiveness. Symptoms include difficulty focusing, forgetfulness, restlessness, and poor time management. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, medications like stimulants (methylphenidate), and educational support.

Pulmonic valve disease affects the valve that controls blood flow from the right ventricle to the lungs. Symptoms include fatigue, shortness of breath, and heart murmur. Treatment may involve monitoring, medications to manage symptoms, or surgical repair or replacement of the valve.

Tietze syndrome is a rare inflammatory condition causing chest wall pain and swelling at the costochondral junctions. Symptoms include localized pain and tenderness that may mimic heart attack. Treatment includes rest, NSAIDs, and corticosteroid injections in resistant cases.

Cranial nerve palsy is the loss of function in one of the twelve cranial nerves, often resulting in facial weakness, vision problems, or difficulty swallowing. Symptoms depend on the affected nerve. Treatment varies by cause and may include medications, physical therapy, or surgery.

Injury to the arm can include fractures, sprains, or soft tissue damage. Symptoms include pain, swelling, limited movement, and bruising. Treatment depends on the type of injury and may include immobilization, ice, pain relief, physical therapy, or surgery.

Conversion disorder involves neurological symptoms like paralysis or seizures that cannot be explained by medical conditions. Symptoms include sudden loss of function or movement, often linked to psychological stress. Treatment includes psychotherapy, physical therapy, and stress management.

Complex regional pain syndrome is a chronic pain condition usually affecting a limb after injury. Symptoms include intense pain, swelling, skin changes, and reduced mobility. Treatment includes physical therapy, pain medications, nerve blocks, and sometimes psychological support.

Otosclerosis is an abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that can lead to hearing loss. Symptoms include progressive hearing loss and sometimes tinnitus. Treatment includes hearing aids or surgery (stapedectomy) to replace the affected bone.

Injury to the trunk can involve the chest, abdomen, or back and may result from trauma. Symptoms vary based on affected structures and can include pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty moving. Treatment ranges from rest and pain management to surgery in severe cases.

Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland underproduces hormones, leading to a slowed metabolism. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and depression. Treatment involves daily use of synthetic thyroid hormone levothyroxine.

Primary insomnia is difficulty falling or staying asleep not caused by other conditions. Symptoms include fatigue, irritability, poor concentration, and reduced daytime function. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), sleep hygiene education, and sometimes medication.

Lice are parasitic insects that infest the scalp or body, causing itching and irritation. Symptoms include intense itching, visible lice or nits, and sores from scratching. Treatment involves topical insecticides like permethrin, manual removal, and treating personal items to prevent reinfestation.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can result from poor diet, malabsorption, or autoimmune conditions. Symptoms include fatigue, numbness, memory problems, and anemia. Treatment includes dietary supplementation, oral or intramuscular vitamin B12 injections.

Diabetes is a chronic condition affecting how the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision, and slow wound healing. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, insulin or oral medications, blood sugar monitoring, and managing complications.

Vulvodynia is chronic pain or discomfort around the opening of the vagina with no identifiable cause. Symptoms include burning, stinging, irritation, or rawness. Treatment may include topical medications, physical therapy, nerve blocks, and psychological counseling.

Endometriosis occurs when tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus. Symptoms include pelvic pain, painful periods, pain during intercourse, and infertility. Treatment includes pain relievers, hormonal therapy, and surgery to remove endometrial growths.

Vasculitis is inflammation of blood vessels, which can restrict blood flow and damage organs. Symptoms vary but may include fever, fatigue, weight loss, and organ-specific issues. Treatment involves corticosteroids and immunosuppressive drugs.

A concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury usually caused by a blow to the head. Symptoms include headache, confusion, dizziness, nausea, and memory loss. Treatment involves rest, gradual return to activities, and monitoring for complications.

Oral leukoplakia is a condition with thick, white patches on the mucous membranes of the mouth, often linked to tobacco use. It's usually painless but may be precancerous. Treatment involves removing the source of irritation and regular monitoring; surgery may be needed.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is the gradual loss of kidney function over time. Symptoms include fatigue, swelling, changes in urination, and high blood pressure. Treatment includes managing underlying causes, dialysis, or kidney transplant in advanced stages.

Bladder disorders include a range of conditions like overactive bladder, interstitial cystitis, and urinary retention. Symptoms may include frequent urination, urgency, pain, or difficulty emptying the bladder. Treatment depends on the cause and may include medication, behavioral therapy, or surgery.

Chorioretinitis is inflammation of the choroid and retina, often due to infections or autoimmune conditions. Symptoms include blurred vision, eye pain, redness, and sensitivity to light. Treatment includes corticosteroids and antimicrobial medications.

Priapism is a prolonged, often painful erection not related to sexual stimulation. It can lead to tissue damage if not treated. Treatment includes medication, drainage of blood from the penis, or surgery in severe cases.

Myositis refers to inflammation of the muscles, leading to weakness, swelling, and pain. It can be caused by autoimmune disease, infections, or medications. Treatment involves corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and physical therapy.

Mononucleosis (mono) is a viral infection typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms include fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue. Treatment involves rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain and fever reducers.

Neuralgia is sharp, shocking pain that follows the path of a nerve, often in the face or neck. It may result from nerve damage or irritation. Treatment includes anticonvulsants, antidepressants, nerve blocks, or surgery in severe cases.

Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder where clusters of cysts form in the kidneys, leading to enlargement and loss of function. Symptoms include high blood pressure, back or side pain, blood in urine, and kidney stones. Treatment involves blood pressure control, pain management, and possibly dialysis or transplant.

Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings including manic and depressive episodes. Symptoms range from high energy and reduced need for sleep to sadness and hopelessness. Treatment includes mood stabilizers, psychotherapy, and lifestyle changes.

Amyloidosis is a condition where abnormal protein deposits (amyloid) accumulate in organs and tissues, impairing function. Symptoms depend on the organ affected and may include fatigue, swelling, weight loss, and neuropathy. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and the underlying cause.

CIDP is a neurological disorder that causes progressive weakness and impaired sensory function in the limbs due to nerve inflammation. Symptoms include tingling, numbness, and muscle weakness. Treatment includes corticosteroids, immunoglobulin therapy, and plasma exchange.

GERD is a chronic digestive disorder where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing irritation. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain. Treatment includes dietary changes, antacids, proton pump inhibitors, and sometimes surgery.

Vitreous hemorrhage is bleeding into the vitreous humor of the eye, often due to trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or retinal tears. Symptoms include sudden vision loss, floaters, or shadows. Treatment includes monitoring, laser therapy, or vitrectomy surgery.

Poisoning due to antimicrobial drugs can occur from overdose or adverse reactions. Symptoms vary by drug but may include nausea, vomiting, confusion, and organ damage. Treatment involves stopping the drug, supportive care, and possibly administering antidotes.

An open wound of the mouth includes cuts or lacerations on the oral mucosa. Symptoms include pain, bleeding, and risk of infection. Treatment involves cleaning the wound, applying antiseptics, pain relief, and sometimes sutures or antibiotics.

Scleroderma is an autoimmune disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening and can affect internal organs. Symptoms include tight skin, joint pain, and digestive issues. Treatment focuses on symptom relief using immunosuppressants, physical therapy, and supportive care.

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder causing weakness in voluntary muscles, especially in the eyes, face, and throat. Symptoms include drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, and fatigue. Treatment includes acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, immunosuppressants, and sometimes thymectomy.

Hypoglycemia is abnormally low blood sugar, often seen in diabetics taking insulin. Symptoms include shakiness, sweating, confusion, and fainting. Treatment involves consuming quick sources of glucose and adjusting medication or meal planning.

Idiopathic absence of menstruation (amenorrhea) is when a woman misses periods for unknown reasons. Symptoms include no menstrual bleeding and potential fertility issues. Treatment depends on hormonal evaluation and may include hormone therapy.

Dislocation of the ankle occurs when the bones in the ankle joint are forced out of alignment, usually due to trauma. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and inability to move the joint. Treatment includes reduction of the dislocation, immobilization, and physical therapy.

carbon monoxide poisoning occurs when carbon monoxide builds up in the bloodstream, typically due to inhaling fumes from fuel-burning appliances. symptoms include headache, dizziness, weakness, nausea, confusion, and loss of consciousness. treatment includes immediate removal from exposure and administration of 100% oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

panic attack is a sudden episode of intense fear or discomfort with no clear danger. symptoms include rapid heartbeat, chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, and fear of losing control. treatment includes breathing techniques, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and anti-anxiety medications.

plantar fasciitis is inflammation of the tissue along the bottom of the foot that connects the heel bone to the toes. symptoms include sharp heel pain, especially in the morning or after rest. treatment includes rest, stretching exercises, orthotics, anti-inflammatory medications, and physical therapy.

hyperopia, or farsightedness, is a refractive error where distant objects are seen more clearly than near ones. symptoms include blurry near vision, eye strain, and headaches. treatment includes corrective lenses or refractive surgery such as LASIK.

poisoning due to sedatives occurs from overdose or misuse of medications like benzodiazepines or barbiturates. symptoms include drowsiness, confusion, slowed breathing, and coma. treatment involves supportive care, activated charcoal, and flumazenil in some cases.

pemphigus is a rare autoimmune disorder causing painful blisters on the skin and mucous membranes. symptoms include fragile blisters, sores, and discomfort in the mouth or skin. treatment includes corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and wound care.

peyronie disease is the development of fibrous scar tissue inside the penis, causing curved, painful erections. symptoms include penile curvature, pain during erection, and erectile dysfunction. treatment includes medications, injections, and in severe cases, surgery.

hiatal hernia occurs when part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm. symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, chest pain, and difficulty swallowing. treatment includes antacids, lifestyle changes, and surgery for severe cases.

extrapyramidal effect of drugs refers to movement disorders caused by certain medications like antipsychotics. symptoms include tremors, rigidity, restlessness, and involuntary movements. treatment includes discontinuing the offending drug and using medications like anticholinergics or benzodiazepines.

meniere disease is a disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. treatment includes low-sodium diet, diuretics, vestibular suppressants, and in severe cases, surgery.

anal fissure is a small tear in the lining of the anus, often caused by passing hard stools. symptoms include pain during bowel movements, bleeding, and itching. treatment includes stool softeners, topical anesthetics, and sometimes surgery.

allergy is an immune system reaction to a foreign substance such as pollen, food, or pet dander. symptoms include sneezing, rash, itching, swelling, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis. treatment includes antihistamines, corticosteroids, avoidance, and immunotherapy.

chronic otitis media is a long-term ear infection that can cause persistent ear discharge and hearing loss. symptoms include fluid drainage, hearing difficulty, and sometimes pain. treatment includes antibiotics, ear drops, and in some cases, surgery like tympanoplasty.

fracture of the finger involves a break in one of the small bones in the finger, usually from trauma. symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and inability to move the finger. treatment includes splinting, pain management, and occasionally surgery.

hirschsprung disease is a congenital condition where nerve cells are missing from parts of the colon, causing blockage. symptoms include constipation, abdominal swelling, and vomiting. treatment is surgical removal of the affected bowel segment.

polymyalgia rheumatica is an inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness, especially in the shoulders and hips. symptoms include aching, fatigue, and stiffness in the morning. treatment includes corticosteroids and physical therapy.

lymphedema is swelling due to lymph fluid buildup, often after lymph node removal or damage. symptoms include persistent swelling, heaviness, and tightness in the limbs. treatment includes compression garments, massage, and exercise.

bladder cancer is the growth of malignant cells in the bladder lining. symptoms include blood in urine, frequent urination, and pain during urination. treatment includes surgery, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and radiation therapy.

acute bronchospasm is the sudden constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles. symptoms include wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness. treatment includes bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and oxygen therapy.

acute glaucoma (angle-closure) is a sudden increase in eye pressure that can lead to vision loss. symptoms include severe eye pain, blurred vision, headache, nausea, and halos around lights. treatment includes medications to reduce pressure and emergency surgery.

open wound of the chest involves a break in the skin and possibly deeper tissues due to trauma. symptoms include bleeding, pain, and visible injury. treatment includes wound cleaning, sutures, antibiotics, and in severe cases, surgery.

dislocation of the patella occurs when the kneecap moves out of its normal position, usually laterally. symptoms include knee pain, swelling, and inability to straighten the leg. treatment includes realignment, immobilization, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

sciatica is pain that radiates along the sciatic nerve, usually from a herniated disk or spinal stenosis. symptoms include lower back pain, leg pain, numbness, and weakness. treatment includes physical therapy, anti-inflammatory drugs, and sometimes surgery.

hypercalcemia is a condition with high calcium levels in the blood, often due to overactive parathyroid glands or cancer. symptoms include nausea, vomiting, confusion, abdominal pain, and muscle weakness. treatment includes IV fluids, diuretics, and medications to reduce calcium.

stress incontinence is involuntary urine leakage during activities that increase abdominal pressure, like coughing or laughing. symptoms include leakage during exertion. treatment includes pelvic floor exercises, bladder training, medications, or surgical options.

varicose veins are enlarged, twisted veins commonly found in the legs due to weakened vein walls and valves. symptoms include visible bulging veins, aching, swelling, and heaviness in the legs. treatment includes compression stockings, leg elevation, sclerotherapy, or laser and surgical interventions.

benign kidney cysts are non-cancerous fluid-filled sacs in the kidneys. symptoms are often absent, but large cysts can cause pain, blood in urine, or high blood pressure. treatment usually isn't needed unless symptoms appear, in which case drainage or surgery may be done.

hydrocele is the accumulation of fluid around a testicle, causing swelling in the scrotum. symptoms include painless scrotal swelling and discomfort. treatment is often observation, but persistent or large hydroceles may require surgical repair.

degenerative disc disease is age-related wear and tear of spinal discs causing back or neck pain. symptoms include pain that worsens with movement, numbness, and weakness. treatment includes physical therapy, pain relievers, steroid injections, or surgery.

hirsutism is excessive, male-pattern hair growth in women, often due to hormonal imbalance or polycystic ovarian syndrome. symptoms include facial and body hair growth. treatment includes hair removal techniques, hormonal therapy, and medications like anti-androgens.

dislocation of the foot occurs when bones in the foot are forced out of alignment, usually from trauma. symptoms include severe pain, swelling, deformity, and inability to walk. treatment includes realignment, immobilization, and possibly surgery.

hydronephrosis is the swelling of a kidney due to urine buildup, often from blockage. symptoms include flank pain, nausea, urinary tract infections, and reduced urine output. treatment includes relieving the blockage with stents, drainage, or surgery.

diverticulosis is the formation of small pouches in the colon wall. symptoms are usually absent, but some people experience bloating, cramps, or constipation. treatment includes high-fiber diet and hydration; complications like diverticulitis require antibiotics or surgery.

pain after an operation is a common post-surgical symptom due to tissue trauma or healing. symptoms include localized pain, swelling, or tenderness. treatment includes pain medications, rest, ice, and physical therapy if necessary.

huntington disease is a genetic neurological disorder causing progressive brain degeneration. symptoms include involuntary movements, cognitive decline, and mood changes. treatment focuses on symptom relief with medications and supportive therapies.

lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system. symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fatigue, fever, weight loss, and night sweats. treatment includes chemotherapy, radiation, immunotherapy, and stem cell transplant.

dermatitis due to sun exposure is skin inflammation caused by excessive UV radiation. symptoms include redness, itching, blistering, and peeling. treatment includes avoiding sun, using moisturizers, topical steroids, and sunscreen.

Disease: anemia due to chronic kidney disease
Description: anemia in chronic kidney disease is caused by reduced erythropoietin production. symptoms include fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath. treatment includes iron supplements, erythropoiesis-stimulating agents, and treating the underlying kidney disease.

injury to internal organs can result from blunt or penetrating trauma. symptoms depend on the organ but may include pain, bleeding, shock, and organ dysfunction. treatment requires imaging, monitoring, and sometimes emergency surgery.

scleritis is inflammation of the white part of the eye (sclera), often linked to autoimmune conditions. symptoms include eye redness, severe pain, and blurred vision. treatment includes corticosteroids and immunosuppressants.

pterygium is a benign growth on the conjunctiva that can extend onto the cornea. symptoms include redness, irritation, and visual disturbance. treatment includes lubricating eye drops and surgical removal if vision is affected.

fungal infections of the skin include conditions like athlete’s foot and ringworm. symptoms include red, scaly, itchy patches. treatment includes topical or oral antifungal medications and hygiene measures.

insulin overdose leads to hypoglycemia. symptoms include sweating, confusion, shakiness, and unconsciousness. treatment includes consuming sugar, glucagon injection, and emergency medical care if severe.

Disease: syndrome of inappropriate secretion of adh (siadh)
Description: siadh is excessive release of antidiuretic hormone, leading to water retention and low sodium. symptoms include headache, confusion, seizures, and nausea. treatment includes fluid restriction, salt tablets, and medications like demeclocycline.

a foreign body in the ear can cause discomfort, hearing loss, or infection. symptoms include pain, discharge, and hearing difficulty. treatment includes careful removal using tools or irrigation by a healthcare provider.

premenstrual tension syndrome (PMS) includes emotional and physical symptoms before menstruation. symptoms include mood swings, bloating, breast tenderness, and fatigue. treatment includes lifestyle changes, pain relievers, hormonal therapy, and antidepressants.

orbital cellulitis is a serious infection of the tissues around the eye. symptoms include eyelid swelling, redness, pain, and vision problems. treatment includes intravenous antibiotics and sometimes surgery.

injury to the leg can include sprains, fractures, or muscle tears. symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and impaired movement. treatment includes rest, ice, compression, elevation, and possibly surgery.

hepatic encephalopathy is brain dysfunction due to liver failure and toxin buildup. symptoms include confusion, lethargy, and coma. treatment includes lactulose, rifaximin, and treating the underlying liver disease.
bone cancer is a malignant tumor in bone tissue. symptoms include bone pain, swelling, and fractures. treatment includes surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and targeted therapy.

syringomyelia is a disorder in which a cyst or cavity forms within the spinal cord. symptoms include muscle weakness, stiffness, pain, and loss of sensitivity, especially in the arms and hands. treatment may involve surgical drainage or decompression to relieve pressure on the spinal cord.

pulmonary fibrosis is a condition where lung tissue becomes scarred, leading to progressive breathing difficulty. symptoms include shortness of breath, chronic dry cough, fatigue, and weight loss. treatment includes antifibrotic medications, oxygen therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, and lung transplant in advanced cases.

mitral valve disease involves damage to the mitral valve of the heart, causing regurgitation or stenosis. symptoms include fatigue, breathlessness, palpitations, and swelling in legs. treatment includes medications like diuretics or beta-blockers and surgical repair or replacement of the valve.

parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative disorder affecting movement. symptoms include tremors, stiffness, slowness of movement, and balance issues. treatment involves medications like levodopa, physical therapy, and in some cases, deep brain stimulation.

gout is a form of arthritis caused by uric acid crystal buildup in joints. symptoms include sudden, severe joint pain, redness, and swelling, often in the big toe. treatment includes anti-inflammatory drugs, urate-lowering medications, and lifestyle changes like reducing alcohol and purine-rich foods.

otitis media is a middle ear infection common in children. symptoms include ear pain, fever, irritability, and temporary hearing loss. treatment includes pain relievers, antibiotics if bacterial, and sometimes ear tubes for recurrent cases.

drug abuse (opioids) involves misuse of prescription or illegal opioids. symptoms include euphoria, sedation, respiratory depression, and dependence. treatment includes medication-assisted therapy (methadone, buprenorphine), counseling, and support groups.

myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of disorders where blood-forming cells in the bone marrow are dysfunctional. symptoms include fatigue, infections, and easy bruising or bleeding. treatment includes blood transfusions, growth factors, chemotherapy, or bone marrow transplant.

fracture of the shoulder typically results from trauma. symptoms include severe shoulder pain, swelling, bruising, and limited mobility. treatment involves immobilization with a sling, pain management, physical therapy, and possibly surgery for complex fractures.

acute kidney injury is a sudden decline in kidney function. symptoms include reduced urine output, swelling, fatigue, confusion, and fluid retention. treatment involves addressing the underlying cause, fluid management, and sometimes dialysis.

threatened pregnancy refers to vaginal bleeding during early pregnancy with a closed cervix and viable fetus. symptoms include abdominal pain and bleeding. treatment includes rest, monitoring, and avoiding strenuous activity; medical evaluation is crucial.

intracranial abscess is a pus-filled infection in the brain. symptoms include headache, fever, neurological deficits, and seizures. treatment includes antibiotics and often surgical drainage of the abscess.

gum disease, or periodontal disease, is an infection of the tissues supporting teeth. symptoms include swollen, bleeding gums, bad breath, and tooth loss. treatment includes professional cleaning, improved oral hygiene, and sometimes surgery.

an open wound from surgical incision may result from dehiscence or poor healing. symptoms include visible wound separation, pain, and discharge. treatment includes wound cleaning, dressing changes, antibiotics, and surgical intervention if needed.

gastrointestinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding in the digestive tract. symptoms include vomiting blood, black or bloody stools, and weakness. treatment includes endoscopy, medications to stop bleeding, blood transfusions, and surgery if severe.

seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition causing red, flaky, itchy patches, especially on the scalp. symptoms include dandruff, greasy scaling, and inflammation. treatment includes medicated shampoos, topical antifungals, and corticosteroids.

drug abuse (methamphetamine) involves misuse of a powerful stimulant. symptoms include euphoria, increased energy, weight loss, aggression, and addiction. treatment includes behavioral therapy, detox programs, and long-term support.

torticollis is a condition where the neck muscles contract, causing the head to twist to one side. symptoms include limited neck movement and pain. treatment includes stretching, physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

poisoning due to antihypertensives can cause dangerously low blood pressure, dizziness, fainting, and organ dysfunction. treatment includes activated charcoal, IV fluids, vasopressors, and close monitoring.

tension headache is a common type of headache caused by muscle tension. symptoms include dull, aching head pain, tightness around the forehead, and neck stiffness. treatment includes pain relievers, stress management, massage, and posture correction.

alcohol intoxication results from excessive alcohol consumption. symptoms include slurred speech, confusion, nausea, vomiting, and impaired coordination. treatment includes supportive care, hydration, and in severe cases, airway management and hospitalization.
scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin c. symptoms include fatigue, swollen gums, joint pain, and bruising. treatment involves vitamin c supplementation and dietary changes.

narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder causing overwhelming daytime drowsiness. symptoms include sudden sleep attacks, cataplexy, hallucinations, and sleep paralysis. treatment includes stimulants, antidepressants, and lifestyle modifications.

food allergy is an immune reaction to specific foods. symptoms range from hives and swelling to anaphylaxis. treatment includes avoiding allergens, antihistamines, and carrying an epinephrine auto-injector.

labyrinthitis is inflammation of the inner ear causing vertigo and imbalance. symptoms include dizziness, nausea, hearing loss, and ringing in the ears. treatment includes vestibular suppressants, anti-nausea medication, and rest.

Anxiety is a common mental health condition characterized by excessive worry, fear, or nervousness that can interfere with daily activities. It may present with symptoms such as restlessness, rapid heartbeat, difficulty concentrating, and sleep problems. While occasional anxiety is a normal stress response, chronic or intense anxiety may indicate an anxiety disorder. Treatment often includes therapy, medication, lifestyle changes, and stress management techniques.

Impulse Control Disorder is a group of psychiatric conditions where individuals struggle to resist urges or impulses that may be harmful to themselves or others. This includes behaviors like compulsive stealing (kleptomania), hair-pulling (trichotillomania), or sudden aggressive outbursts. People often feel tension before the act and relief afterward, but may experience guilt later. Treatment typically involves psychotherapy, behavioral therapy, and sometimes medication.

Stenosis of the Tear Duct, also called nasolacrimal duct obstruction, is a narrowing or blockage of the duct that drains tears from the eye into the nose. This condition can lead to excessive tearing, recurrent eye infections, and inflammation. It may be present at birth (congenital) or develop later due to infection, injury, or aging. Treatment can include warm compresses, massage, antibiotics, or surgical procedures like dacryocystorhinostomy to restore drainage.

A nasal abscess is a collection of pus inside or around the nose, often resulting from infection, trauma, or an untreated pimple or boil. It can cause swelling, redness, pain, and sometimes fever. If left untreated, it can spread and lead to serious complications. Treatment usually includes drainage and antibiotics.

Omphalitis is an infection of the umbilical stump in newborns, often occurring within the first few days of life. It presents with redness, swelling, foul odor, and discharge around the navel. It's considered a medical emergency as the infection can spread quickly. Prompt treatment with antibiotics is essential.

Leukemia is a type of cancer affecting the blood and bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells. Symptoms may include fatigue, frequent infections, easy bruising or bleeding, and weight loss. Treatment depends on the type (e.g., ALL, AML, CLL, CML) and may involve chemotherapy, radiation, targeted therapy, or stem cell transplant.

Bell’s palsy is a sudden, temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, typically on one side of the face. It is believed to result from inflammation of the facial nerve, often triggered by a viral infection. Symptoms include drooping of one side of the face, difficulty closing the eye, and impaired facial expressions. Most people recover fully with or without treatment.

Allergic conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva (the thin membrane covering the eye) caused by allergens like pollen, dust, or pet dander. It leads to redness, itching, tearing, and swelling in both eyes. It is not contagious and is managed with antihistamines, avoiding allergens, and lubricating eye drops.

A drug reaction (also called adverse drug reaction or drug hypersensitivity) is an unwanted or harmful response to a medication. Reactions can range from mild (such as rashes, nausea, or drowsiness) to severe (such as anaphylaxis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, or organ damage). These reactions may be allergic, toxic, or idiosyncratic. Management includes discontinuing the offending drug and providing appropriate supportive or emergency care.

Adrenal cancer is a rare but aggressive cancer that forms in the adrenal glands, located above the kidneys. It may cause excess hormone production, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, high blood pressure, muscle weakness, or hormonal imbalances (e.g., Cushing’s syndrome). Some tumors are non-functioning and discovered incidentally. Treatment typically involves surgery, with possible chemotherapy or radiation in advanced cases.

Myopia, or nearsightedness, is a common refractive error where close objects appear clear, but distant objects are blurry. It occurs when the eyeball is too long or the cornea is too curved, causing light rays to focus in front of the retina. Myopia often develops during childhood and progresses over time. It can be corrected with glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery.

Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in joints. This leads to pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced motion, commonly affecting the knees, hips, hands, and spine. It is a degenerative disease associated with aging, joint injury, or obesity. Treatment includes physical therapy, medications, and in some cases, joint replacement surgery.

Thyroid disease encompasses various disorders that affect the thyroid gland, such as hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid), hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), thyroid nodules, and thyroid cancer. Symptoms vary based on the condition but may include weight changes, fatigue, temperature sensitivity, or mood changes. Treatment depends on the specific diagnosis and may involve medications, surgery, or radioactive iodine therapy.

Pharyngitis is inflammation of the pharynx, commonly referred to as a sore throat. It can be caused by viral infections (like the common cold or flu) or bacterial infections (such as strep throat). Symptoms include throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and swollen lymph nodes. Most cases are mild and resolve on their own, but bacterial cases may require antibiotics.

Chronic rheumatic fever is a long-term complication of rheumatic fever, an inflammatory disease that can develop after a Group A streptococcal throat infection. It primarily affects the heart, particularly the valves, and may lead to rheumatic heart disease. Other complications can involve the joints, skin, and brain. Management includes antibiotics to prevent recurrence and medications to manage heart issues.

Hypocalcemia is a condition marked by low levels of calcium in the blood. It can result from vitamin D deficiency, kidney disease, or parathyroid dysfunction. Symptoms may include muscle cramps, tingling in the fingers, fatigue, and in severe cases, cardiac arrhythmias or seizures. Treatment involves calcium and vitamin D supplementation and addressing the underlying cause.

Macular degeneration, specifically age-related macular degeneration (AMD), is a common eye disorder among people over 50. It affects the macula, the central part of the retina, leading to blurred or loss of central vision. There are two types: dry (more common, slower progression) and wet (less common, faster and more severe). While it can’t be cured, treatments like anti-VEGF injections and vision aids can help manage symptoms.

Pneumonia is a lung infection caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. It leads to inflammation of the air sacs, which may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough, fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. Severity ranges from mild to life-threatening, especially in the elderly or those with weakened immunity. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics, antivirals, or supportive care like oxygen therapy

Cold sores, also known as fever blisters, are painful, fluid-filled lesions that typically appear around the lips or mouth. They are caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). The infection is contagious and can be triggered by stress, illness, or sun exposure. While there’s no cure, antiviral medications can help reduce the severity and frequency of outbreaks.

PVCs are extra heartbeats that originate in the ventricles and disrupt the regular heart rhythm. They are common and often harmless, especially in healthy individuals. Symptoms can include palpitations, a fluttering feeling, or skipped beats. However, frequent PVCs may be linked to heart disease and should be evaluated if they cause significant symptoms or occur often.

Testicular cancer originates in the testicles and is most common in younger men (ages 15–35). It often presents as a painless lump or swelling in the testicle. While relatively rare, it is one of the most treatable forms of cancer, especially when detected early. Treatment typically involves surgery and may include chemotherapy or radiation.

Hydrocephalus is the buildup of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain’s ventricles, leading to increased pressure. It can be congenital or acquired (due to injury, infection, or tumor). Symptoms include an unusually large head in infants, headaches, nausea, balance problems, and cognitive issues. Treatment involves surgical placement of a shunt or endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) to drain excess fluid.

Breast cancer develops in breast tissue, most often in the ducts or lobules. It is one of the most common cancers in women, but it can also affect men. Signs include a breast lump, changes in shape or skin, or nipple discharge. Early detection via mammograms significantly improves outcomes. Treatment may include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, or targeted drugs

Anemia due to malignancy occurs when cancer or its treatment disrupts red blood cell production or increases destruction. It can result from bone marrow involvement, bleeding, nutritional deficiencies, or chemotherapy side effects. Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. Management focuses on treating the underlying cancer and may involve blood transfusions or erythropoiesis-stimulating agents.

Esophageal varices are swollen veins in the lower esophagus, often due to increased pressure from liver cirrhosis (portal hypertension). They pose a serious risk of rupture and bleeding, which is a medical emergency. Symptoms of bleeding varices include vomiting blood, black stools, and shock. Treatment includes medications, endoscopic banding, and procedures to reduce portal pressure.

Endometrial cancer arises from the lining of the uterus (endometrium) and is the most common gynecologic cancer. It usually affects postmenopausal women and often presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding. Risk factors include obesity, hormonal imbalances, and age. Treatment involves surgery (hysterectomy), possibly followed by radiation or chemotherapy depending on the stage.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system by causing thick, sticky mucus buildup. It leads to chronic lung infections and poor nutrient absorption. Common symptoms include persistent cough, frequent lung infections, and failure to gain weight. There is no cure, but treatments like airway clearance, enzyme supplements, and CFTR modulators improve quality of life.

Intertrigo is a skin condition caused by inflammation in warm, moist body folds (like under the breasts, groin, or armpits). It often appears as red, raw, itchy rashes and may become secondarily infected with bacteria or yeast. It’s common in people who are overweight or sweat excessively. Treatment involves keeping the area dry, using antifungal or antibacterial creams, and improving hygiene.

A parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of a parathyroid gland, causing overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH). This leads to primary hyperparathyroidism, resulting in high calcium levels (hypercalcemia). Symptoms include fatigue, kidney stones, bone pain, and abdominal discomfort. Treatment typically involves surgical removal of the adenoma.

Glucocorticoid deficiency, often due to adrenal insufficiency or Addison’s disease, results in inadequate cortisol production. Symptoms include fatigue, low blood pressure, weight loss, and skin darkening. It can be life-threatening if not treated.
