Diagnosis involves hormone testing, and treatment includes lifelong hormone replacement with hydrocortisone or similar steroids.

TMJ disorder affects the joint that connects the jawbone to the skull, leading to pain in the jaw and surrounding muscles. Symptoms include jaw pain, clicking or popping sounds, difficulty chewing, and headaches. Causes range from arthritis and jaw injury to stress-related teeth grinding. Treatment includes physical therapy, medications, bite guards, and sometimes surgery.

Wilson disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other organs. Symptoms include liver disease, neurological issues (tremors, difficulty speaking), and psychiatric problems. It usually appears in childhood or early adulthood. Treatment includes lifelong use of medications like chelators to remove excess copper and dietary modifications.

VUR is a condition where urine flows backward from the bladder into the ureters or kidneys. It is most common in infants and children and can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and kidney damage. Diagnosis is often made with imaging tests. Mild cases may resolve with age, while severe cases might need surgery or long-term antibiotics.

Vitamin A deficiency impairs vision, especially night vision, and increases the risk of infections. It is common in developing countries and can lead to xerophthalmia (dry eyes), poor immune function, and skin issues. In severe cases, it may cause blindness. Treatment involves dietary changes and vitamin A supplementation.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It affects the genital tract, rectum, and throat. Common symptoms include painful urination, abnormal discharge, and pelvic pain, although many cases are asymptomatic. Untreated gonorrhea can lead to infertility and systemic complications. It is treated with antibiotics.

A rib fracture is a break or crack in one of the rib bones, often caused by trauma such as a fall or car accident. Symptoms include sharp chest pain that worsens with breathing, coughing, or movement. Most rib fractures heal on their own with rest and pain control, but severe cases may require hospitalization to monitor for complications like lung injury.

Ependymoma is a rare tumor that arises from ependymal cells lining the brain's ventricles or the spinal cord. It can occur at any age but is more common in children. Symptoms depend on tumor location and may include headaches, nausea, balance issues, and spinal symptoms. Treatment typically involves surgery, possibly followed by radiation.

Toxic hepatitis occurs when the liver becomes inflamed due to exposure to harmful substances like drugs, alcohol, or industrial chemicals. Symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, nausea, and abdominal pain. The condition can be acute or chronic and, in severe cases, lead to liver failure. Treatment focuses on stopping exposure to the toxin and supporting liver function.

Vaginal cysts are fluid-filled sacs that form in or around the vaginal wall. They are often small and painless but may become tender or infected. Common types include Bartholin’s cysts and Gartner duct cysts. Most require no treatment unless symptomatic, in which case drainage or surgical removal may be needed.

An open wound on the shoulder refers to any break in the skin in the shoulder area caused by trauma (cuts, punctures, abrasions). It carries a risk of infection, especially if deep or contaminated. Initial management includes cleaning, dressing, and possibly stitches or antibiotics. Severe wounds may require surgical care.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, usually in a fallopian tube. It cannot proceed normally and can cause life-threatening bleeding if untreated. Symptoms include sharp pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, and dizziness. Immediate medical intervention is necessary, often involving medication or surgery.

Chronic knee pain persists over time and may result from injury, arthritis, overuse, or structural problems. Common causes include osteoarthritis, ligament damage, or meniscus tears. Symptoms include swelling, stiffness, instability, and reduced range of motion. Management includes physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

A pinguecula is a non-cancerous, yellowish bump on the white part of the eye near the cornea, often caused by sun exposure, wind, or dust. It is usually harmless but can cause irritation or dryness. Lubricating eye drops help, and surgery is rare but may be needed for cosmetic or comfort reasons.

Hypergammaglobulinemia refers to elevated levels of immunoglobulins (antibodies) in the blood, often due to chronic infections, autoimmune disorders, or certain cancers. It may be asymptomatic or associated with fatigue, recurrent infections, or inflammation. Diagnosis is via blood tests, and treatment depends on the underlying cause.

Alcohol abuse involves consuming alcohol in a harmful or compulsive way, leading to health, social, or legal problems. It can result in liver disease, brain damage, addiction, and mental health issues. Treatment includes counseling, medications, rehabilitation, and support groups like Alcoholics Anonymous (AA).

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by pressure on the median nerve in the wrist, leading to numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hand and fingers. Repetitive wrist movements, pregnancy, or conditions like diabetes increase risk. Treatment includes wrist splints, corticosteroid injections, and sometimes surgery.

Pituitary disorders affect the pituitary gland, which regulates key hormones. Tumors (like adenomas), injury, or inflammation can disrupt hormone production, leading to growth problems, fatigue, infertility, or vision changes. Diagnosis involves hormone tests and imaging. Treatment may include medication, surgery, or hormone therapy.

A kidney stone is a hard deposit of minerals and salts that forms in the kidneys. Symptoms include sharp back or side pain, blood in urine, and nausea. Small stones may pass on their own, but larger ones might require medication, shock wave therapy, or surgery.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by challenges with communication, social interaction, and repetitive behaviors. The severity varies widely. Early diagnosis and interventions such as behavioral therapy, speech therapy, and educational support can improve outcomes.

Cat scratch disease is a bacterial infection (from Bartonella henselae) usually transmitted through a scratch or bite from an infected cat. It causes swollen lymph nodes, fever, and fatigue. Most cases are mild and resolve on their own, but antibiotics may be needed in severe cases.

Chronic (open-angle) glaucoma is a progressive eye disease where increased intraocular pressure damages the optic nerve, often without early symptoms. It can lead to gradual vision loss and eventual blindness if untreated. Management includes medicated eye drops, laser therapy, or surgery to lower eye pressure.

Retinal detachment occurs when the retina pulls away from the tissue supporting it, cutting off blood and oxygen. This is a medical emergency and can cause permanent vision loss. Symptoms include flashes of light, floaters, or a shadow over vision. Treatment typically involves surgery.

Aplastic anemia is a rare but serious condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells. It may result from autoimmune diseases, toxins, infections, or genetics. Symptoms include fatigue, infections, and easy bruising. Treatment options include medications, blood transfusions, or bone marrow transplant.

Overflow incontinence is the involuntary release of urine due to a bladder that doesn’t empty properly, often because of nerve damage or an obstruction. Symptoms include frequent or constant dribbling of urine. Treatment involves medications, catheterization, or surgery depending on the underlying cause.

Hemolytic anemia occurs when red blood cells are destroyed faster than they can be made. Causes can be autoimmune diseases, infections, medications, or inherited conditions. Symptoms include fatigue, jaundice, and shortness of breath. Treatment depends on the cause and may involve steroids, transfusions, or immunosuppressants.

Tennis elbow is inflammation or microtearing of the tendons that join the forearm muscles on the outside of the elbow. It results from overuse or repetitive motion. Symptoms include pain and weakness in the arm. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, anti-inflammatories, and sometimes injections.

An open eye wound is a laceration or puncture to the eyeball or surrounding tissue. It's a medical emergency that can lead to infection, vision loss, or other complications. Treatment includes protecting the eye, antibiotics, and often surgery by an ophthalmologist.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It progresses in stages and can affect many organs if untreated. Early symptoms include sores and rashes. It's curable with antibiotics, usually penicillin, but early detection is crucial.

Also called diabetic nephropathy, this is a serious complication of diabetes where high blood sugar damages the kidneys’ filtering ability. It can lead to chronic kidney disease and kidney failure. Management includes controlling blood sugar and blood pressure, and sometimes dialysis or transplant.

Nose disorders encompass a variety of issues like sinusitis, nasal polyps, deviated septum, and infections. Symptoms vary but often include congestion, runny nose, pain, or bleeding. Treatment depends on the condition and may involve medication, nasal sprays, or surgery.

Drug withdrawal refers to the symptoms that occur after stopping or reducing intake of addictive substances. Common symptoms include anxiety, irritability, sweating, nausea, and insomnia. Treatment may involve gradual tapering of the drug, supportive care, and in some cases, medications to ease symptoms.

Dental caries (tooth decay) is caused by bacterial action on sugars that leads to enamel destruction and cavities. Symptoms include tooth pain, sensitivity, and visible holes. Treatment involves removal of decayed material and filling, fluoride application, or in severe cases, root canal or extraction.

Hypercholesterolemia is the presence of high levels of cholesterol in the blood, increasing risk of heart disease and stroke. It typically has no symptoms but may be detected by blood tests. Treatment includes lifestyle changes like diet and exercise, and medications such as statins.

A fracture of the patella (kneecap) is usually due to trauma or a fall. Symptoms include pain, swelling, inability to straighten the knee, and bruising. Treatment can involve immobilization with a cast or brace, or surgery if the bone is displaced.

Kidney failure occurs when the kidneys can't filter waste from the blood effectively. Symptoms include fatigue, swelling, decreased urine output, and confusion. Treatment may involve dialysis, medications, dietary changes, or a kidney transplant in advanced cases.

A neck fracture refers to a break in one of the cervical vertebrae. Symptoms include neck pain, limited mobility, numbness, or even paralysis. Emergency treatment includes immobilization, and long-term care may involve surgery, traction, or a cervical collar.

Muscle spasms are sudden, involuntary muscle contractions often caused by overuse, dehydration, or mineral deficiency. Symptoms include pain, stiffness, and twitching. Treatment involves stretching, massage, hydration, and sometimes medications like muscle relaxants.

Hemophilia is a genetic disorder where blood does not clot properly, leading to prolonged bleeding. Symptoms include spontaneous bleeding, easy bruising, and joint pain from internal bleeding. Treatment involves replacement therapy with clotting factors and avoiding injury.

This is a severe complication of diabetes, marked by extremely high blood sugar and dehydration, but with minimal ketones. Symptoms include confusion, weakness, dry mouth, and unconsciousness. Treatment involves intravenous fluids, insulin, and electrolyte replacement in a hospital setting.

A peritonsillar abscess is a pus-filled infection beside the tonsil, often a complication of tonsillitis. Symptoms include severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, muffled voice, and fever. Treatment includes drainage of the abscess and antibiotics.

Gastroparesis is a condition where the stomach empties slowly due to nerve dysfunction, often linked to diabetes. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, bloating, early satiety, and abdominal pain. Treatment includes dietary modifications, medications to stimulate stomach muscles, and in severe cases, feeding tubes.

Unexplained itching (pruritus) can result from dry skin, systemic disease, or neurological causes without visible rash. Symptoms include persistent itching and discomfort. Treatment may include moisturizers, antihistamines, topical steroids, or evaluation for underlying systemic issues.

Polycythemia vera is a rare blood cancer where the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, leading to thickened blood. Symptoms include headache, dizziness, itching after showers, and blood clots. Treatment involves phlebotomy, low-dose aspirin, and medications to suppress blood production.

Thrombocytopenia is a condition with low platelet count, leading to increased bleeding risk. Symptoms include easy bruising, prolonged bleeding, petechiae, and fatigue. Treatment depends on the cause and may include corticosteroids, platelet transfusions, or treating underlying conditions.

Head and neck cancers include malignancies in the mouth, throat, larynx, or sinuses. Symptoms include lumps, sore throat, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing. Treatment includes surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, or targeted therapy based on the tumor type and stage.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is a rare inherited condition where the body is resistant to parathyroid hormone. Symptoms include low calcium levels, muscle cramps, tingling, and developmental delays. Treatment includes calcium and vitamin D supplements to correct the imbalance.

A goiter is an enlargement of the thyroid gland, often due to iodine deficiency, autoimmune disease, or thyroid dysfunction. Symptoms include neck swelling, difficulty breathing or swallowing. Treatment varies from observation to iodine supplementation, medication, or surgery.

Urge incontinence involves a sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by involuntary leakage. It may be caused by infections, neurological disorders, or overactive bladder. Treatment includes bladder training, pelvic floor exercises, medications, and lifestyle changes.

Edward syndrome (trisomy 18) is a genetic disorder caused by an extra chromosome 18. Symptoms include severe developmental delays, heart defects, and distinct facial features. There is no cure, and treatment focuses on supportive care and improving quality of life.

An open wound on the arm refers to a break in the skin due to injury. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and risk of infection. Treatment includes cleaning, dressing, tetanus prophylaxis, and stitches or surgical intervention if necessary.

Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic disorders causing progressive muscle weakness and wasting. Symptoms vary by type but often include difficulty walking, muscle cramps, and loss of mobility. There is no cure; treatment includes physical therapy, braces, and corticosteroids.

Mittelschmerz is mid-cycle ovulation pain experienced by some women. Symptoms include a one-sided lower abdominal ache or sharp pain. It is generally benign and self-limiting. Treatment includes pain relievers or hormonal birth control if symptoms are severe.

A corneal abrasion is a scratch on the eye’s surface. Symptoms include eye pain, redness, tearing, and light sensitivity. Treatment involves antibiotic eye drops, lubricating ointments, and sometimes an eye patch to promote healing.

Anemia of chronic disease occurs due to long-term inflammation, infection, or malignancy. Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Treatment focuses on managing the underlying condition and may include erythropoiesis-stimulating agents.

Dysthymic disorder (persistent depressive disorder) is a chronic form of depression lasting two or more years. Symptoms include low mood, fatigue, poor concentration, and low self-esteem. Treatment includes psychotherapy, antidepressant medications, and lifestyle modifications.

Scarlet fever is a bacterial illness resulting from strep throat and marked by a red rash. Symptoms include sore throat, fever, red tongue, and rash. Treatment includes antibiotics and symptomatic relief with fluids and antipyretics.

Hypertensive heart disease results from prolonged high blood pressure, leading to heart failure or arrhythmias. Symptoms include chest pain, breathlessness, and palpitations. Treatment involves blood pressure control, lifestyle changes, and cardiac medications.

Barbiturate abuse involves misuse of sedative drugs, leading to dependence, respiratory depression, and overdose. Symptoms include drowsiness, confusion, and slurred speech. Treatment includes detoxification under supervision, therapy, and long-term rehabilitation programs.

PCOS is a hormonal disorder in women characterized by irregular periods, excess androgens, and ovarian cysts. Symptoms include acne, hair growth, obesity, and infertility. Treatment involves hormonal birth control, weight management, and medications like metformin.

Encephalitis is brain inflammation usually due to viral infection. Symptoms include fever, confusion, seizures, and altered consciousness. Treatment includes antiviral medications, supportive care, and hospitalization in severe cases.

A cyst of the eyelid, often a chalazion or stye, forms when an oil gland becomes blocked. Symptoms include a small bump, swelling, tenderness, or redness on the eyelid. Treatment may involve warm compresses, antibiotics for infection, or surgical drainage if persistent.

Balanitis is inflammation of the head of the penis, often due to poor hygiene, infections, or irritation. Symptoms include redness, pain, swelling, and sometimes discharge. Treatment involves improved hygiene, antifungal or antibiotic creams, and avoiding irritants.

A foreign body in the throat occurs when an object like food or a small item becomes lodged. Symptoms include choking, pain, difficulty swallowing, or coughing. Treatment involves removal by medical professionals and monitoring for complications like infection.

Cocaine abuse involves using the stimulant drug for euphoria, leading to addiction and severe health issues. Symptoms include elevated heart rate, paranoia, aggression, and heart problems. Treatment includes detox, behavioral therapy, and long-term rehabilitation.

Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve, often linked to multiple sclerosis. Symptoms include sudden vision loss in one eye, pain with eye movement, and color vision changes. Treatment includes corticosteroids and addressing the underlying neurological condition.

Alcohol withdrawal occurs when a person with alcohol dependence stops drinking suddenly. Symptoms range from tremors and anxiety to seizures and delirium tremens. Treatment involves medical supervision, benzodiazepines, fluids, and nutritional support.

PACs are early heartbeats originating in the atria. Symptoms may include palpitations, skipped beats, or no symptoms at all. They are often benign but may require treatment if frequent—options include lifestyle changes, avoiding stimulants, and medications.

Hemiplegia is paralysis of one side of the body, commonly resulting from stroke or brain injury. Symptoms include weakness or complete loss of movement on one side. Treatment involves rehabilitation, physical therapy, and addressing the underlying cause.

Hammer toe is a foot deformity where a toe becomes bent at the middle joint, often from wearing tight shoes. Symptoms include pain, corns, and difficulty walking. Treatment includes footwear changes, orthotics, exercises, and possibly surgery.

An open wound of the cheek can result from trauma or cuts. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and risk of infection. Treatment involves cleaning, suturing if necessary, antibiotics, and wound care to promote healing.

Joint effusion refers to excess fluid in a joint, often due to injury, arthritis, or infection. Symptoms include swelling, stiffness, and pain. Treatment depends on the cause and may involve rest, anti-inflammatories, aspiration, or joint injections.

An open wound of the knee is a break in the skin due to trauma. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and possible joint involvement. Treatment includes cleaning, wound closure, antibiotics, and tetanus prophylaxis if needed.

A meningioma is a typically benign tumor of the meninges, the brain's outer lining. Symptoms depend on size and location but may include headaches, seizures, and neurological deficits. Treatment includes monitoring, surgery, or radiation.

Brain cancer involves malignant tumors in the brain or spinal cord. Symptoms include headaches, seizures, cognitive changes, and weakness. Treatment includes surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and supportive care depending on the tumor type and stage.

Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus during pregnancy. Symptoms include vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and fetal distress. It is a medical emergency treated with hospitalization and possibly early delivery.

Hay fever is an allergic reaction to airborne substances like pollen. Symptoms include sneezing, runny nose, itchy eyes, and congestion. Treatment includes antihistamines, nasal sprays, and allergen avoidance.

Lung cancer is a malignancy of lung tissue, often related to smoking. Symptoms include cough, weight loss, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Treatment depends on the type and stage and includes surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and immunotherapy.

Primary kidney disease refers to intrinsic kidney disorders like glomerulonephritis or nephrotic syndrome. Symptoms include proteinuria, swelling, fatigue, and high blood pressure. Treatment depends on the cause and may include medications, dietary changes, and dialysis.

Uterine cancer, most often endometrial cancer, arises from the lining of the uterus. Symptoms include abnormal vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, and weight loss. Treatment includes surgery, radiation, hormone therapy, or chemotherapy.

Dry eye of unknown cause involves inadequate tear production or poor tear quality. Symptoms include irritation, burning, and blurred vision. Treatment includes artificial tears, punctal plugs, and sometimes anti-inflammatory eye drops like cyclosporine.

Fibrocystic breast disease causes noncancerous changes in breast tissue, resulting in lumpiness, tenderness, and sometimes pain, especially before menstruation. Symptoms include swollen, rope-like breast tissue and discomfort. Treatment includes supportive bras, reducing caffeine, pain relievers, and hormone therapy in severe cases.

Fungal infections of the hair (tinea capitis) are caused by dermatophytes and mostly affect children. Symptoms include scalp itching, scaling, hair loss in patches, and black dots. Treatment involves oral antifungal medications like griseofulvin or terbinafine, and antifungal shampoos to reduce transmission.

A tooth abscess is a pocket of pus caused by bacterial infection in or around a tooth. Symptoms include severe toothache, sensitivity, fever, and swelling in the face or jaw. Treatment includes drainage of the abscess, antibiotics, root canal treatment, or tooth extraction.

Disease: envenomation from spider or animal bite
Description: Envenomation occurs when venom is injected through a bite or sting from animals like spiders or snakes. Symptoms vary based on the animal but can include pain, swelling, redness, nausea, and neurological symptoms. Treatment involves wound care, pain relief, antivenom, and monitoring for systemic reactions.

VACTERL association is a non-random group of birth defects affecting the vertebrae, anus, heart, trachea, esophagus, kidneys, and limbs. Symptoms depend on the affected organs and are usually present at birth. Treatment is surgical and multidisciplinary, addressing each defect individually.

Vertebrobasilar insufficiency is reduced blood flow to the back of the brain, often due to atherosclerosis. Symptoms include dizziness, visual disturbances, unsteadiness, and fainting. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, blood pressure and cholesterol control, and sometimes surgery or stenting.

Rectal disorders include conditions like hemorrhoids, fissures, and rectal prolapse. Symptoms may involve bleeding, pain, itching, and prolapse. Treatment varies and includes diet changes, topical treatments, minimally invasive procedures, or surgery.

Atonic bladder is a condition where the bladder muscles lose tone and cannot contract properly, leading to urinary retention or overflow incontinence. Symptoms include inability to void completely, dribbling, and infections. Treatment includes catheterization, bladder training, and treating underlying causes like neuropathy.

BPPV is a vestibular disorder that causes brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head movements. Symptoms include spinning sensation, dizziness, and balance issues. Treatment includes canalith repositioning maneuvers (e.g., Epley maneuver) and vestibular rehabilitation therapy.

Blepharospasm is involuntary contraction of the eyelid muscles causing excessive blinking or eye closure. Symptoms include eye irritation, twitching, and vision disruption. Treatment includes botulinum toxin injections, medications, and in rare cases, surgery on eyelid muscles.

Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease where small clumps of inflammatory cells (granulomas) form in organs, commonly the lungs and lymph nodes. Symptoms include cough, fatigue, and skin or eye lesions. Treatment includes corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and symptom monitoring.

Metastatic cancer is cancer that has spread from its original site to other parts of the body. Symptoms depend on the location but may include pain, fatigue, and organ dysfunction. Treatment includes systemic therapies like chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, and palliative care.

Trigger finger occurs when inflammation narrows the space around a tendon in the finger, causing pain and locking. Symptoms include stiffness, a popping sensation, and a finger stuck in a bent position. Treatment includes rest, splints, steroid injections, and sometimes surgery.

A stye is a red, painful bump near the edge of the eyelid caused by bacterial infection of oil glands. Symptoms include swelling, tenderness, and tearing. Treatment includes warm compresses, good hygiene, and antibiotics if infection spreads.

Hemochromatosis is a disorder causing excess iron buildup in the body, potentially damaging organs. Symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, diabetes, and skin darkening. Treatment involves regular blood removal (phlebotomy), iron chelation, and dietary adjustments.

Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that usually develops near growth plates in children and adolescents. Symptoms may include a painless bump, restricted movement, or irritation of nearby tissues. Treatment is observation or surgical removal if painful or deforming.

Cushing syndrome results from prolonged exposure to high cortisol levels. Symptoms include weight gain, round face, purple stretch marks, and high blood pressure. Treatment depends on the cause—stopping steroids, surgery for tumors, or medications to reduce cortisol production.

Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi. Symptoms include high fever, abdominal pain, rash, and diarrhea or constipation. Treatment involves antibiotics like ciprofloxacin or ceftriaxone, hydration, and rest.

Vitreous degeneration involves the breakdown of the gel-like substance inside the eye with age. Symptoms include floaters, flashes, or blurred vision. Treatment is usually not needed unless retinal detachment occurs, which requires surgery.

Atrophic skin conditions involve thinning of the skin, often from aging, steroids, or underlying disease. Symptoms include fragile, wrinkled skin with visible blood vessels. Treatment involves minimizing steroid use, sun protection, and moisturizers to improve skin health.

Aspergillosis is a fungal infection caused by Aspergillus species, commonly affecting the lungs. Symptoms vary by type but may include cough, wheezing, shortness of breath, and fever. Treatment involves antifungal medications like voriconazole and sometimes surgical removal of fungal masses.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract effectively after childbirth, leading to postpartum hemorrhage. Symptoms include heavy vaginal bleeding and a soft, enlarged uterus. Treatment includes uterine massage, medications to stimulate contractions (e.g., oxytocin), and surgical interventions if bleeding persists.

Trichinosis is a parasitic infection caused by eating undercooked meat (usually pork) infected with Trichinella larvae. Symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, muscle pain, fever, and swelling around the eyes. Treatment includes antiparasitic medications like albendazole, pain relief, and corticosteroids in severe cases.

Whooping cough (pertussis) is a highly contagious bacterial infection marked by severe coughing fits that end with a "whoop" sound. Symptoms include cold-like signs, followed by intense coughing and vomiting. Treatment includes antibiotics such as azithromycin and supportive care, along with vaccination for prevention.

An open wound of the lip is a break in the skin due to trauma, leading to pain, bleeding, and swelling. Symptoms include visible tissue damage and possible infection. Treatment includes cleaning the wound, sutures if needed, and antibiotics or tetanus shots if indicated.

Subacute thyroiditis is a temporary inflammation of the thyroid, often following a viral infection. Symptoms include neck pain, fever, fatigue, and transient hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism. Treatment includes NSAIDs or corticosteroids for inflammation and beta blockers for thyroid-related symptoms.

Oral mucosal lesions are abnormal areas in the lining of the mouth due to infections, trauma, or systemic conditions. Symptoms include redness, ulcers, or white patches. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antifungals, antivirals, corticosteroids, or improved oral hygiene.

An open wound due to trauma is a skin injury caused by an external force, such as a cut, laceration, or abrasion. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and risk of infection. Treatment includes wound cleaning, closure with sutures or bandages, and tetanus prophylaxis if necessary.

Intracerebral hemorrhage is bleeding within the brain tissue, usually due to high blood pressure, trauma, or aneurysms. Symptoms include sudden headache, weakness, confusion, and loss of consciousness. Treatment involves controlling bleeding and intracranial pressure, sometimes requiring surgery or intensive care.

Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that causes memory loss, confusion, personality changes, and impaired daily functioning. Symptoms worsen over time. Treatment includes medications like donepezil and memantine to slow progression and supportive care for safety and quality of life.

Vaginismus is an involuntary tightening of vaginal muscles during intercourse or penetration, often caused by psychological or physical factors. Symptoms include pain, burning, and inability to have penetrative sex. Treatment involves pelvic floor therapy, counseling, and use of vaginal dilators.

SLE is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks various organs and tissues. Symptoms include joint pain, skin rashes, fatigue, kidney issues, and photosensitivity. Treatment includes corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and antimalarials like hydroxychloroquine.

Premature ovarian failure is early loss of normal ovarian function before age 40, leading to infertility and menopause-like symptoms. Symptoms include irregular periods, hot flashes, and mood swings. Treatment includes hormone replacement therapy and fertility support if desired.

Thoracic outlet syndrome occurs when nerves or blood vessels are compressed between the collarbone and first rib. Symptoms include pain, tingling, and weakness in the arms or neck. Treatment includes physical therapy, posture correction, pain management, and surgery in severe cases.

A ganglion cyst is a noncancerous lump filled with fluid, usually on the wrist or hand. Symptoms include swelling, discomfort, and sometimes limited joint movement. Treatment includes observation, aspiration, or surgical removal if painful or limiting.

Knee dislocation occurs when the bones of the knee are out of place, often from trauma. Symptoms include intense pain, swelling, and visible deformity. Treatment involves immediate reduction (repositioning), immobilization, physical therapy, and sometimes surgical repair of ligaments.

Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the digestive tract. Symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss. Treatment includes anti-inflammatory medications, immunosuppressants, dietary management, and surgery in severe cases.

A postoperative infection occurs after surgery due to contamination of the surgical site. Symptoms include redness, swelling, fever, pain, and pus discharge. Treatment involves antibiotics, wound care, and sometimes reopening and draining the wound.

Folate deficiency occurs due to inadequate dietary intake, absorption issues, or alcoholism. Symptoms include fatigue, pallor, tongue soreness, and megaloblastic anemia. Treatment includes folic acid supplementation and dietary changes to include leafy greens and fortified foods.

Fluid overload is excess fluid in the body, often due to heart failure, kidney disease, or excessive IV fluids. Symptoms include swelling, shortness of breath, and weight gain. Treatment includes diuretics, fluid restriction, and treating the underlying cause.

Atrial flutter is a type of abnormal heart rhythm where the atria beat too quickly. Symptoms include palpitations, shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest discomfort. Treatment involves medications to control heart rate or rhythm, cardioversion, and catheter ablation.

Skin disorders refer to a broad range of conditions affecting the skin, including eczema, acne, and dermatitis. Symptoms vary widely but may include redness, itching, rashes, or lesions. Treatment depends on the specific condition and may involve topical creams, oral medications, or lifestyle changes.

Floaters are small spots or threads drifting in the field of vision, caused by changes in the vitreous humor of the eye. Symptoms include seeing specks, cobwebs, or shadows. Most cases are harmless, but sudden onset may need evaluation. Treatment is typically observation; surgery is rare.

Tooth disorders include cavities, abscesses, and enamel erosion. Symptoms vary but can include pain, sensitivity, swelling, or bad breath. Treatment includes fillings, root canal therapy, extractions, or antibiotics for infections, along with good oral hygiene and dental checkups.

A heart attack (myocardial infarction) occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is blocked, damaging the heart muscle. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and arm or jaw pain. Emergency treatment includes aspirin, nitroglycerin, angioplasty, or bypass surgery.

An open wound of the abdomen refers to a break in the skin and underlying tissues due to trauma or surgery. Symptoms include pain, bleeding, and possible organ exposure. Treatment involves wound cleaning, suturing, antibiotics, and monitoring for infection or internal injury.

A leg fracture is a break in one of the leg bones (femur, tibia, or fibula). Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty walking. Treatment includes immobilization with a cast or brace, pain control, and sometimes surgical fixation with plates or rods.

Oral thrush is a fungal infection of the mouth caused by Candida. Symptoms include white patches on the tongue and inner cheeks, redness, soreness, and difficulty swallowing. Treatment involves antifungal medications like nystatin or fluconazole and addressing underlying causes.

Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting skin rash of unknown cause, often starting with a "herald patch" followed by a widespread rash. Symptoms include oval pink or red patches and mild itching. Treatment is usually not needed, but antihistamines or corticosteroids may relieve itching.

Animal allergies occur when the immune system reacts to proteins found in animal skin cells, urine, or saliva. Symptoms include sneezing, runny nose, itchy eyes, and asthma. Treatment includes antihistamines, nasal sprays, avoiding exposure, and allergy shots in severe cases.

Orthostatic hypotension is a sudden drop in blood pressure when standing up, causing dizziness or fainting. Symptoms include lightheadedness, blurred vision, and weakness. Treatment includes increasing fluid and salt intake, wearing compression stockings, and medications like fludrocortisone.

OSA is a condition where throat muscles intermittently relax during sleep, blocking the airway. Symptoms include loud snoring, daytime sleepiness, and poor concentration. Treatment involves CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure), weight loss, and sometimes surgery.

Hypokalemia is a low potassium level in the blood, which can affect muscle and heart function. Symptoms include weakness, cramps, fatigue, and arrhythmias. Treatment involves oral or IV potassium supplements and correcting the underlying cause such as diuretic use or vomiting.

Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, leading to red, scaly plaques. Symptoms include itching, burning, and flaking skin. Treatment includes topical steroids, phototherapy, systemic immunosuppressants, and lifestyle changes.

Shoulder dislocation occurs when the upper arm bone slips out of the shoulder socket. Symptoms include severe pain, swelling, and limited motion. Treatment involves manual reduction, immobilization, pain relief, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery for recurrent cases.

Intussusception is a condition where one part of the intestine slides into another, causing blockage. It mostly affects infants and young children. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools. Treatment includes air enema reduction or surgery.

Cervicitis is inflammation of the cervix, often due to infection. Symptoms include vaginal discharge, pelvic pain, bleeding between periods, or during intercourse. Treatment includes antibiotics or antiviral medications depending on the cause, and partner treatment if sexually transmitted.

A pharyngeal abscess is a collection of pus in the throat caused by bacterial infection. Symptoms include sore throat, fever, difficulty swallowing, and swollen lymph nodes. Treatment involves antibiotics and sometimes surgical drainage of the abscess.

Primary thrombocythemia is a rare blood disorder where the bone marrow produces too many platelets. Symptoms include clotting or bleeding, headaches, and dizziness. Treatment includes low-dose aspirin, platelet-lowering medications like hydroxyurea, and regular monitoring.

Arthritis of the hip causes inflammation and degeneration of the hip joint, leading to pain and stiffness. Symptoms include reduced range of motion, limping, and difficulty standing or walking. Treatment includes physical therapy, pain relievers, joint injections, and hip replacement in severe cases.

Decubitus ulcers, or pressure sores, are injuries to the skin and underlying tissue from prolonged pressure on the skin. Symptoms include skin discoloration, pain, open wounds, and signs of infection. Treatment includes relieving pressure, cleaning wounds, using dressings, antibiotics if infected, and in severe cases, surgery.

Hypernatremia is a high concentration of sodium in the blood, often caused by dehydration or underlying health issues. Symptoms include thirst, confusion, muscle twitching, and seizures. Treatment involves slow correction of sodium levels with intravenous fluids and addressing the underlying cause.

Sensorineural hearing loss is caused by damage to the inner ear or auditory nerve. Symptoms include partial or total loss of hearing, difficulty understanding speech, and tinnitus. Treatment options include hearing aids, cochlear implants, or therapies depending on the severity and cause.

Chronic ulcers are long-lasting sores that fail to heal, often found on the legs or feet. Symptoms include persistent open wounds, pain, swelling, and drainage. Treatment includes wound care, compression therapy, antibiotics if infected, and managing underlying conditions like diabetes or poor circulation.

Osteoporosis is a condition where bones become weak and brittle. Symptoms may include back pain, loss of height, and fractures from minor falls. Treatment includes calcium and vitamin D supplements, medications to strengthen bones, weight-bearing exercises, and lifestyle changes.

Ileus is a temporary lack of movement in the intestines, causing a blockage. Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment involves bowel rest, IV fluids, nasogastric suction, and treating the underlying cause.

Sickle cell crisis is a painful episode due to blocked blood flow from abnormally shaped red blood cells. Symptoms include severe pain, swelling, fever, and shortness of breath. Treatment involves pain management, hydration, oxygen, and sometimes blood transfusions.

Urethritis is inflammation of the urethra, usually due to infection. Symptoms include painful urination, discharge, and increased urge to urinate. Treatment typically involves antibiotics or antiviral medications depending on the cause.

Prostatitis is inflammation of the prostate gland, which may be bacterial or non-bacterial. Symptoms include pelvic pain, painful urination, difficulty urinating, and sometimes fever. Treatment includes antibiotics, anti-inflammatory medications, and pain relievers.

Otitis externa is an infection of the outer ear canal, often due to moisture. Symptoms include ear pain, itching, swelling, and drainage. Treatment includes cleaning the ear canal, antibiotic or antifungal ear drops, and keeping the ear dry.

Poisoning due to anticonvulsants occurs when these drugs are taken in excessive doses. Symptoms include dizziness, confusion, tremors, and respiratory depression. Treatment involves supportive care, activated charcoal, and monitoring in a medical setting.

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord, cutting off blood supply to the testicle. Symptoms include sudden severe scrotal pain, swelling, and nausea. It is a surgical emergency and requires immediate intervention to save the testicle.

Tricuspid valve disease affects the valve between the right atrium and right ventricle of the heart. Symptoms include fatigue, swelling, shortness of breath, and heart palpitations. Treatment includes medications for heart failure and surgery for valve repair or replacement.

Urethral stricture is narrowing of the urethra due to injury, infection, or inflammation. Symptoms include reduced urine stream, straining, and urinary retention. Treatment options include dilation, urethrotomy, or surgical reconstruction.

Vitamin D deficiency can lead to bone pain, muscle weakness, and fatigue. It may cause rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Treatment involves vitamin D supplementation, dietary changes, and increased sun exposure.

A hydatidiform mole is an abnormal pregnancy where a tumor forms in the uterus. Symptoms include abnormal vaginal bleeding, high hCG levels, and an enlarged uterus. Treatment involves uterine evacuation and monitoring hCG levels to ensure resolution.

This condition involves chronic neck pain without a clear cause. Symptoms include stiffness, reduced mobility, and persistent discomfort. Treatment includes physical therapy, pain medications, heat/cold therapy, and sometimes injections.

Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Symptoms include a persistent cough, weight loss, night sweats, and fever. Treatment includes a long course of antibiotics over several months, often involving multiple drugs.

A pelvic fistula is an abnormal connection between pelvic organs, often between the bladder, vagina, or rectum. Symptoms include abnormal discharge, recurrent infections, and urinary or fecal incontinence. Treatment usually involves surgical repair.

Acute bronchiolitis is a viral infection of the small airways in the lungs, common in infants. Symptoms include coughing, wheezing, difficulty breathing, and feeding problems. Treatment is usually supportive, including oxygen, fluids, and sometimes hospitalization.

Presbyopia is an age-related condition where the eye gradually loses the ability to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print and eye strain. Treatment includes reading glasses, bifocals, contact lenses, or corrective surgery like LASIK.

Dementia is a group of conditions affecting memory, thinking, and social abilities severely enough to interfere with daily life. Symptoms include memory loss, confusion, difficulty with communication, and personality changes. Treatment focuses on slowing progression with medications, cognitive therapies, and supportive care.

An insect bite occurs when an insect punctures the skin. Symptoms include redness, itching, swelling, and in some cases, allergic reactions. Treatment includes antihistamines, topical creams, and cold compresses. Severe reactions may require emergency medical attention.

Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia is a sudden episode of fast heart rate originating in the ventricles. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, chest pain, and fainting. Treatment includes antiarrhythmic medications, electrical cardioversion, or ablation therapy.

A congenital heart defect is a structural abnormality in the heart present at birth. Symptoms vary by type but may include cyanosis, shortness of breath, and poor feeding in infants. Treatment ranges from monitoring to medications and corrective heart surgery.

Connective tissue disorders affect the tissues supporting organs and structures in the body. Symptoms include joint pain, skin changes, and organ dysfunction. Treatment depends on the specific disorder and may involve immunosuppressants, pain management, and physical therapy.

This occurs when a particle like dust, metal, or an insect gets into the eye. Symptoms include irritation, redness, tearing, and blurred vision. Treatment involves flushing the eye with saline or removing the object, and seeking medical care if embedded.

Gas poisoning typically refers to inhalation of toxic gases like carbon monoxide. Symptoms include headache, dizziness, confusion, and shortness of breath. Treatment includes immediate fresh air, oxygen therapy, and hospitalization in severe cases.

This refers to bacterial skin infections causing pus formation. Symptoms include redness, swelling, warmth, and discharge. Treatment includes antibiotics, drainage of abscesses, and proper wound care.

Endometrial hyperplasia is thickening of the uterine lining, often due to estrogen imbalance. Symptoms include heavy or irregular menstrual bleeding. Treatment includes hormonal therapy and, in some cases, surgical procedures like dilation and curettage.

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by dark, velvety patches in body folds. It's often associated with insulin resistance. Symptoms are cosmetic but may signal an underlying condition. Treatment focuses on managing the cause and using topical creams.

Central atherosclerosis involves plaque buildup in large central arteries. Symptoms depend on affected vessels but may include chest pain or limb pain. Treatment involves lifestyle changes, medications to lower cholesterol and blood pressure, and sometimes surgery.

Viral exanthem is a widespread rash caused by a viral infection. Symptoms include red rashes, fever, and fatigue. Treatment is usually supportive, including rest, fluids, and antipyretics. Most cases resolve without complications.

This is inflammation of the stomach and intestines not caused by infection, often from medications or food intolerance. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Treatment involves hydration, dietary adjustments, and stopping the irritant.

BPH is a non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland. Symptoms include frequent urination, weak stream, and incomplete bladder emptying. Treatment includes medications like alpha-blockers or 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors, and sometimes surgery.

Menopause is the natural cessation of menstruation, typically occurring in women over 45. Symptoms include hot flashes, mood changes, and sleep disturbances. Treatment includes hormone replacement therapy, lifestyle changes, and symptom-specific medications.

This is a group of disorders where part of the immune system is missing or doesn't function properly. Symptoms include frequent infections, poor wound healing, and fatigue. Treatment involves immunoglobulin therapy, antibiotics, and in some cases, stem cell transplants.

Ovarian cancer is a malignant growth in the ovaries. Symptoms are often vague but include bloating, pelvic pain, and urinary urgency. Treatment includes surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes targeted therapy depending on the stage.

A cataract is a clouding of the lens in the eye that affects vision. Symptoms include blurry vision, sensitivity to light, and difficulty seeing at night. Treatment involves surgical removal of the cloudy lens and replacement with an artificial one.

This occurs when the head of the femur is forced out of the hip socket. Symptoms include severe pain, inability to move the leg, and deformity. Treatment involves emergency reduction, pain management, and rehabilitation.

Spinal stenosis is the narrowing of the spinal canal, which can compress the spinal cord or nerves. Symptoms include back pain, numbness, weakness, and difficulty walking. Treatment includes physical therapy, pain relievers, steroid injections, and sometimes decompression surgery.

Intestinal obstruction occurs when part of the intestine is blocked, preventing the passage of contents. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain, bloating, vomiting, and constipation. Treatment involves bowel rest, nasogastric suction, IV fluids, and sometimes surgery to remove the blockage.

A heart contusion is a bruise to the heart muscle usually caused by blunt trauma. Symptoms may include chest pain, irregular heartbeat, and shortness of breath. Treatment is supportive and includes monitoring, oxygen therapy, and managing complications such as arrhythmias.

Congenital malformation syndrome involves multiple birth defects that occur together due to genetic or environmental causes. Symptoms vary widely depending on the syndrome but may include physical deformities, developmental delays, or organ dysfunction. Treatment is tailored to the specific malformations and may involve surgery, therapy, and multidisciplinary care.

Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection that typically affects the skin, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Symptoms include nodular skin lesions that may ulcerate. Treatment includes antifungal medications such as itraconazole, and potassium iodide in some cases.

Lymphangitis is an inflammation of the lymphatic channels, usually due to bacterial infection. Symptoms include red streaks on the skin, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and pain. Treatment includes antibiotics, pain relievers, and addressing the source of infection.

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is a neurological disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often linked to alcoholism. Symptoms include confusion, ataxia, memory loss, and eye movement problems. Treatment involves immediate thiamine replacement and managing alcohol use.

Intestinal diseases include a range of disorders affecting the gastrointestinal tract, such as IBS, Crohn’s disease, and colitis. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and weight loss. Treatment depends on the condition and can include dietary changes, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Acute bronchitis is inflammation of the bronchial tubes, often due to a viral infection. Symptoms include cough, chest discomfort, mild fever, and fatigue. Treatment is usually supportive with rest, fluids, and cough suppressants. Antibiotics are rarely needed.

Persistent vomiting of unknown cause involves repeated vomiting without a clear diagnosis. Symptoms include nausea, dehydration, weight loss, and electrolyte imbalance. Treatment focuses on hydration, antiemetic medications, and diagnostic evaluation to identify the underlying cause.

An open wound of the foot can result from injury, leading to exposed tissue. Symptoms include pain, bleeding, swelling, and risk of infection. Treatment includes cleaning the wound, applying dressings, possibly antibiotics, and monitoring for healing or complications.

Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle, often due to viral infections. Symptoms include chest pain, fatigue, arrhythmias, and shortness of breath. Treatment may involve rest, medications for heart function, and in severe cases, hospitalization or mechanical support.

Preeclampsia is a pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and signs of organ damage, typically after 20 weeks of gestation. Symptoms include swelling, headaches, vision changes, and elevated liver enzymes. Treatment includes monitoring, medications to lower blood pressure, and delivery of the baby if necessary.

Ischemic heart disease is caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle, often due to coronary artery disease. Symptoms include chest pain (angina), shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, medications, and possibly procedures like angioplasty or bypass surgery.

Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder causing tumors to form on nerve tissue. Symptoms include skin spots, neurofibromas, and in some cases, learning disabilities and bone deformities. Treatment involves monitoring, surgery to remove tumors, and supportive therapies.

Chickenpox is a viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus. Symptoms include an itchy rash with blisters, fever, and fatigue. Treatment includes rest, antihistamines for itching, antiviral medications in some cases, and vaccination for prevention.

Pancreatic cancer is a malignancy of the pancreas often detected late. Symptoms include abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, and fatigue. Treatment may involve surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and palliative care depending on the stage.

Drug-induced neuropathy is nerve damage caused by certain medications. Symptoms include numbness, tingling, burning pain, and weakness. Treatment includes stopping the causative drug, using pain management strategies, and physical therapy.

Croup is a viral infection that causes swelling in the upper airway, mostly in young children. Symptoms include a barking cough, hoarseness, and difficulty breathing. Treatment includes humidified air, corticosteroids, and in severe cases, hospitalization.

Idiopathic excessive menstruation refers to heavy menstrual bleeding without an identifiable cause. Symptoms include prolonged bleeding, fatigue, and anemia. Treatment includes hormonal therapy, antifibrinolytics, and sometimes surgical options like endometrial ablation.

Amblyopia, also known as lazy eye, is a vision development disorder where one eye fails to achieve normal visual acuity. Symptoms may include poor depth perception, squinting, and eye misalignment. Treatment involves patching the stronger eye, using corrective glasses, or vision therapy to strengthen the weaker eye.

Meckel diverticulum is a congenital pouch in the lower small intestine. It may cause symptoms like abdominal pain, bleeding, or bowel obstruction. Treatment typically involves surgical removal if symptomatic.

Dislocation of the wrist occurs when the bones in the wrist are forced out of alignment, usually due to trauma. Symptoms include intense pain, swelling, and deformity. Treatment includes realignment (reduction), immobilization with a cast or splint, and physical therapy.

Ear drum damage or perforation can result from trauma, infection, or loud noises. Symptoms include pain, hearing loss, tinnitus, and possible discharge. Treatment includes keeping the ear dry, antibiotics if infected, and surgical repair (tympanoplasty) in severe cases.

Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual activity. Symptoms include reduced sexual desire and difficulty with erections. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, medications like sildenafil, counseling, or mechanical devices.

Disease: temporary or benign blood in urine
Description: Benign hematuria refers to non-threatening causes of blood in the urine, often from vigorous exercise, minor trauma, or menstruation. It may be asymptomatic or cause visible red urine. Treatment is not usually needed but underlying causes should be ruled out.

Disease: kidney disease due to longstanding hypertension
Description: Chronic high blood pressure can damage kidneys, leading to hypertensive nephropathy. Symptoms may include proteinuria, edema, and reduced kidney function. Treatment focuses on controlling blood pressure and protecting kidney function with ACE inhibitors or ARBs.

Chondromalacia patella is the softening or breakdown of cartilage under the kneecap. Symptoms include knee pain when climbing stairs or sitting long periods. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medications, and sometimes surgery.

Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nail, causing discoloration, thickening, and brittleness. Treatment includes antifungal oral or topical medications and, in some cases, removal of the infected nail.

Urethral disorders can include inflammation, stricture, or infection of the urethra. Symptoms may include painful urination, urinary retention, and discharge. Treatment depends on the cause and can include antibiotics, dilation, or surgery.

Lyme disease is a bacterial infection transmitted by tick bites. Symptoms include a bullseye rash, fever, joint pain, and neurological issues in later stages. Treatment involves antibiotics like doxycycline or amoxicillin.

Iron deficiency anemia occurs when there's not enough iron to make adequate hemoglobin. Symptoms include fatigue, pallor, shortness of breath, and brittle nails. Treatment includes dietary iron, supplements, and treating the underlying cause of iron loss.

ARDS is a severe lung condition where fluid fills the alveoli, often due to trauma, infection, or inflammation. Symptoms include severe shortness of breath, rapid breathing, and low oxygen levels. Treatment includes mechanical ventilation and supportive care in the ICU.

Toxic multinodular goiter is an enlarged thyroid with multiple nodules producing excess hormones. Symptoms include weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Treatment includes radioactive iodine, antithyroid drugs, or thyroidectomy.

An open wound of the finger is a break in the skin due to injury. Symptoms include pain, bleeding, and possible infection. Treatment includes cleaning, dressing, tetanus prophylaxis, and stitches if needed.

Autonomic nervous system disorders affect involuntary body functions like heart rate and digestion. Symptoms may include dizziness, fainting, irregular heartbeat, and digestive issues. Treatment involves managing symptoms with medications, lifestyle changes, and treating the underlying cause.

Psychosexual disorders affect sexual functioning or behavior. Symptoms vary and may include lack of desire, arousal issues, or identity conflicts. Treatment includes counseling, psychotherapy, and sometimes medication.

Anemia is a condition where the blood lacks enough healthy red cells or hemoglobin. Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pallor, and shortness of breath. Treatment depends on the cause and may include iron supplements, vitamin B12, or treatment of chronic conditions.

Tendinitis is inflammation of a tendon, usually from overuse or injury. Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, and limited movement. Treatment includes rest, ice, anti-inflammatory medications, and physical therapy.

The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. Symptoms include sore throat, runny nose, cough, and congestion. Treatment is supportive, including rest, fluids, decongestants, and pain relievers.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Symptoms include muscle twitching, difficulty speaking, swallowing, and breathing. There is no cure, but treatments like riluzole and edaravone may slow progression. Supportive care includes physical therapy, speech therapy, and assistive devices.

Disease: central retinal artery or vein occlusion
Description: Central retinal artery or vein occlusion is a blockage of the main blood vessels to the retina, leading to sudden, painless vision loss in one eye. Symptoms include partial or complete vision loss and floaters. Treatment depends on the cause and may include anti-VEGF injections, laser therapy, or medications to lower intraocular pressure or treat underlying conditions.

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) is a sudden, rapid heartbeat originating above the heart's ventricles. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, chest discomfort, and shortness of breath. Treatment may include vagal maneuvers, medications like beta-blockers, or catheter ablation in severe or recurrent cases.

Venous insufficiency occurs when veins have trouble sending blood from the legs back to the heart. Symptoms include leg swelling, varicose veins, aching, and skin changes. Treatments include compression stockings, leg elevation, weight management, and sometimes surgical procedures or vein ablation.

Trichomonas infection is a sexually transmitted infection caused by a parasite. Symptoms in women include vaginal discharge, itching, and pain during urination; men are often asymptomatic. Treatment is with oral metronidazole or tinidazole for both partners to prevent reinfection.

Acne is a skin condition caused by clogged hair follicles with oil and dead skin. Symptoms include pimples, blackheads, and cysts, mostly on the face, back, and chest. Treatment includes topical retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics, and oral medications like isotretinoin for severe cases.

Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent sadness, loss of interest, and difficulty functioning. Symptoms include fatigue, sleep disturbances, appetite changes, and thoughts of self-harm. Treatment includes psychotherapy (like CBT), antidepressants, and lifestyle changes.

Drug abuse is the misuse of legal or illegal substances, leading to health, social, or legal issues. Symptoms vary by substance but often include behavioral changes, cravings, withdrawal, and tolerance. Treatment involves detoxification, counseling, behavioral therapy, support groups, and sometimes medication-assisted therapy.

Urinary tract obstruction is a blockage that impedes the flow of urine. Symptoms include flank pain, difficulty urinating, and urinary retention. Treatment depends on the cause and location and may involve catheterization, surgery, or medications to relieve the obstruction.

Diabetes insipidus is a rare disorder causing excessive urination and thirst due to antidiuretic hormone (ADH) imbalance. Symptoms include frequent urination, dehydration, and excessive thirst. Treatment involves hormone replacement (desmopressin) and addressing underlying causes.

Iridocyclitis is inflammation of the iris and ciliary body in the eye, often associated with autoimmune disorders. Symptoms include eye pain, redness, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light. Treatment includes corticosteroid eye drops, pupil dilators, and managing underlying conditions.

Varicocele is the enlargement of veins within the scrotum, similar to varicose veins. Symptoms include a dull ache or visible enlarged veins, and it may affect fertility. Treatment includes scrotal support, pain management, or surgical ligation or embolization in severe cases.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder. Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and constipation. Treatment involves dietary changes (like low-FODMAP diet), stress management, and medications like antispasmodics or fiber supplements.

Fracture of the foot involves a break in one or more bones in the foot due to trauma or overuse. Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty walking. Treatment may include rest, immobilization with a cast or boot, and sometimes surgery.

Ovarian cysts are fluid-filled sacs on the ovaries. Many are asymptomatic, but larger cysts can cause pelvic pain, bloating, and menstrual irregularities. Treatment may include watchful waiting, hormonal therapy, or surgical removal if symptomatic or suspicious.

Chlamydia is a common bacterial sexually transmitted infection. Symptoms include genital discharge and burning during urination, but many cases are asymptomatic. Treatment is with antibiotics, typically azithromycin or doxycycline, and partner treatment is essential.

Parasitic diseases are caused by organisms such as protozoa, helminths, or ectoparasites. Symptoms vary by parasite but may include diarrhea, abdominal pain, fatigue, and skin rashes. Treatment depends on the organism and includes antiparasitic medications like albendazole or metronidazole.

Fracture of the jaw (mandibular fracture) typically results from trauma. Symptoms include jaw pain, swelling, bruising, difficulty chewing, and misaligned teeth. Treatment includes immobilization, surgery for severe fractures, and pain management.
Lipoma is a benign fatty tumor under the skin. It usually presents as a soft, painless lump. Treatment is not necessary unless it causes discomfort or cosmetic concern; surgical removal is an option.

Female genitalia infections include conditions like bacterial vaginosis, yeast infections, and STIs. Symptoms may include discharge, itching, odor, and irritation. Treatment depends on the cause and includes antifungal or antibiotic medications.

Pulmonary hypertension is high blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs, which can lead to heart failure. Symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain, and swelling in the legs. Treatment includes medications like vasodilators, diuretics, oxygen therapy, and sometimes lung or heart-lung transplantation.

A thyroid nodule is a lump in the thyroid gland, often benign but occasionally cancerous. Symptoms are usually absent, but large nodules may cause swallowing difficulties or neck discomfort. Treatment includes monitoring, thyroid hormone therapy, or surgical removal if suspicious or symptomatic.

A broken tooth can result from trauma, decay, or biting hard objects. Symptoms include pain, sensitivity, and visible cracks. Treatment includes dental bonding, crowns, root canals, or extraction depending on severity.

Dumping syndrome occurs when food moves too quickly from the stomach to the small intestine, often after gastric surgery. Symptoms include nausea, diarrhea, bloating, dizziness, and rapid heartbeat. Treatment includes dietary changes (small, low-sugar meals), medications, and sometimes surgery.

Lymphadenitis is inflammation of the lymph nodes due to infection. Symptoms include swollen, tender lymph nodes, fever, and redness over the affected area. Treatment involves antibiotics for bacterial causes, and pain relief; severe cases may require drainage.

Facial injuries include cuts, fractures, and soft tissue damage. Symptoms depend on severity and include pain, swelling, bruising, and bleeding. Treatment ranges from wound care and pain management to surgical repair.

Aortic valve disease involves the narrowing (stenosis) or leaking (regurgitation) of the aortic valve. Symptoms include chest pain, fatigue, shortness of breath, and fainting. Treatment may include medications, monitoring, or valve replacement surgery.

Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease causing chronic joint inflammation. Symptoms include joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and fatigue. Treatment includes disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), biologics, NSAIDs, and physical therapy.

A spermatocele is a fluid-filled cyst in the epididymis of the testicle. It is usually painless and found incidentally. Treatment is generally not needed unless it causes discomfort, in which case surgical removal may be done.

Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection, common in children. Symptoms include red sores that rupture and form a honey-colored crust. Treatment includes topical or oral antibiotics and maintaining hygiene to prevent spread.

An anal fistula is an abnormal tunnel between the anal canal and the skin. Symptoms include pain, swelling, discharge, and irritation. Treatment usually requires surgery (fistulotomy) to remove or close the tract.

Hypothermia occurs when body temperature drops below 95°F (35°C), often due to prolonged cold exposure. Symptoms include shivering, confusion, slurred speech, and loss of coordination. Treatment involves warming the body through blankets, warm fluids, and in severe cases, advanced medical rewarming techniques.

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is a behavioral condition in children characterized by defiance, irritability, and hostility toward authority figures. Symptoms include frequent temper loss, argumentativeness, and spiteful behavior. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, parent training, and sometimes medication for coexisting conditions.

Migraine is a neurological condition marked by intense, throbbing headaches, often with nausea, sensitivity to light and sound, and visual disturbances (auras). Treatment includes pain relievers, triptans, anti-nausea medications, and preventive drugs like beta-blockers or anti-seizure medications.

Diabetic peripheral neuropathy is nerve damage from prolonged high blood sugar levels. Symptoms include tingling, burning, numbness, and pain in the extremities. Treatment focuses on blood sugar control, pain relief (with antidepressants or anticonvulsants), and foot care.

Testicular disorders include inflammation, infection, trauma, or tumors affecting the testicles. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, lumps, or infertility. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics, pain management, or surgery.

Gestational diabetes is high blood sugar during pregnancy. It often has no symptoms but can cause complications for the mother and baby. Treatment includes diet management, blood sugar monitoring, physical activity, and insulin if needed.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic skin condition with painful lumps under the skin, typically in armpits or groin. Symptoms include blackheads, pus-filled lumps, and scarring. Treatment includes antibiotics, anti-inflammatory medications, hormone therapy, and surgical removal of affected tissue.

Valley fever (coccidioidomycosis) is a fungal infection from inhaling spores found in soil, mostly in the southwestern U.S. Symptoms include fever, cough, fatigue, and chest pain. Most cases resolve without treatment, but antifungal medications are used in moderate to severe cases.

Bacterial conjunctivitis is an eye infection causing redness, swelling, discharge, and crusting. It spreads easily through contact. Treatment includes antibiotic eye drops or ointment and hygiene measures to prevent transmission.

Lewy body dementia is a progressive brain disorder caused by abnormal protein deposits in the brain. Symptoms include fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, Parkinson-like movement problems, and sleep disturbances. Treatment includes cholinesterase inhibitors, antipsychotics (used cautiously), and supportive therapies.

Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells in the bone marrow. Symptoms include bone pain, fatigue, frequent infections, and kidney dysfunction. Treatment includes chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, stem cell transplant, and supportive care for bone health and anemia.

A head injury can range from a mild concussion to a severe traumatic brain injury. Symptoms include headache, confusion, dizziness, nausea, and in severe cases, unconsciousness. Treatment depends on severity and includes rest, medication for symptoms, and emergency care for serious trauma.

Ascending cholangitis is a bacterial infection of the bile ducts, often due to obstruction (like gallstones). Symptoms include fever, jaundice, abdominal pain, and confusion. It’s a medical emergency treated with IV antibiotics and often an ERCP procedure to remove the blockage.

This condition involves unpredictable periods with no identifiable cause. Symptoms include irregular timing, flow, or missed periods. Treatment includes hormonal birth control to regulate cycles, lifestyle changes, and monitoring for underlying conditions like PCOS or thyroid disorders.

Interstitial lung disease is a group of disorders causing scarring in lung tissue. Symptoms include dry cough, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment includes corticosteroids, antifibrotic agents, oxygen therapy, and in severe cases, lung transplantation.

Mononeuritis (or mononeuropathy) is damage to a single peripheral nerve, often due to diabetes or trauma. Symptoms include pain, weakness, or numbness in the affected area. Treatment includes managing the underlying condition, pain control, and physical therapy.

Malaria is a mosquito-borne parasitic infection. Symptoms include fever, chills, sweating, headache, and muscle pain. Severe cases may involve organ failure. Treatment includes antimalarial medications like artemisinin-based combinations or chloroquine, depending on the region and parasite resistance.

Somatization disorder (now called somatic symptom disorder) is characterized by excessive focus on physical symptoms without a clear medical cause. Symptoms include pain, fatigue, and gastrointestinal issues. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), stress management, and sometimes antidepressants.

Hypovolemia is a condition of decreased blood volume, usually due to bleeding, dehydration, or fluid loss. Symptoms include low blood pressure, dizziness, rapid heart rate, and fainting. Treatment includes fluid replacement, treating the underlying cause, and in severe cases, blood transfusion.

Schizophrenia is a chronic mental health disorder affecting thinking, emotions, and behavior. Symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, and social withdrawal. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications, psychotherapy, and social support.

This involves damage to ligaments (ACL, MCL) or the meniscus in the knee. Symptoms include pain, swelling, instability, and limited range of motion. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, bracing, and possibly surgical repair.

Endocarditis is an infection of the heart’s inner lining or valves. Symptoms include fever, fatigue, heart murmur, and embolic events. Treatment includes long-term IV antibiotics and possibly surgery to repair or replace damaged valves.

Sepsis is the body’s extreme response to an infection, leading to life-threatening organ dysfunction. Symptoms include fever, rapid heartbeat, confusion, low blood pressure, and shortness of breath. Treatment requires hospitalization, IV antibiotics, fluids, and support for failing organs.

Heat stroke is a severe heat-related illness with body temperature above 104°F (40°C). Symptoms include confusion, rapid heartbeat, hot dry skin, and unconsciousness. It is a medical emergency treated with rapid cooling, IV fluids, and supportive care.

Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, often due to gallstones. Symptoms include right upper abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment includes fasting, IV fluids, antibiotics, and in some cases, gallbladder removal surgery.

Cardiac arrest is the sudden loss of heart function. Symptoms include collapse, no pulse, and no breathing. Immediate treatment includes CPR, defibrillation, and emergency medical intervention. Long-term care involves identifying and treating the underlying cause.

Cardiomyopathy is a disease of the heart muscle that affects its ability to pump blood. Symptoms include fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in the legs. Treatment depends on type and may include medications, lifestyle changes, implanted devices, or heart transplant.

Social phobia (social anxiety disorder) is an intense fear of being judged or embarrassed in social situations. Symptoms include blushing, sweating, trembling, and avoidance of social events. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy and medications like SSRIs or beta-blockers.

Meningitis is inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, caused by viruses, bacteria, or fungi. Symptoms include fever, headache, stiff neck, sensitivity to light, and confusion. Treatment depends on cause: antibiotics for bacterial, supportive care for viral, and antifungals for fungal types.

Spherocytosis is a genetic condition affecting red blood cells, making them sphere-shaped and prone to breakdown. Symptoms include anemia, jaundice, fatigue, and an enlarged spleen. Treatment includes folic acid supplements, blood transfusions, and in some cases, splenectomy (removal of the spleen).

Hormone disorders involve imbalances in the body’s endocrine system, affecting growth, metabolism, mood, and reproduction. Symptoms vary but may include weight changes, fatigue, mood swings, or menstrual irregularities. Treatment depends on the specific disorder and can include hormone replacement, medications, or surgery.

Raynaud disease is a condition where blood flow to fingers and toes is reduced in response to cold or stress. Symptoms include color changes in the skin (white, blue, red), numbness, and pain. Treatment includes keeping warm, stress management, and vasodilator medications.

Reactive arthritis is joint inflammation triggered by an infection elsewhere in the body, often in the urinary or gastrointestinal tract. Symptoms include joint pain, swelling, conjunctivitis, and urinary symptoms. Treatment includes NSAIDs, antibiotics for underlying infection, and physical therapy.

Scabies is a contagious skin infestation caused by microscopic mites. Symptoms include intense itching, especially at night, and a pimple-like rash. Treatment includes topical permethrin or oral ivermectin and washing all clothing and bedding.

Ear wax impaction occurs when earwax builds up and blocks the ear canal. Symptoms include hearing loss, earache, fullness, and tinnitus. Treatment involves ear drops to soften wax, irrigation, or manual removal by a healthcare provider.
