Hypertension during pregnancy includes gestational hypertension and preeclampsia. Symptoms may include high blood pressure, swelling, protein in urine, and headaches. Treatment includes close monitoring, medications, and early delivery if necessary for maternal or fetal safety.

Peripheral arterial embolism is the sudden blockage of an artery, usually in the legs, by a clot or debris. Symptoms include pain, coldness, numbness, and loss of pulse in the affected limb. Treatment includes anticoagulants, thrombolytics, or surgical removal of the clot.

Rosacea is a chronic skin condition that causes facial redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes acne-like bumps. Symptoms can also include eye irritation and thickened skin. Treatment includes topical or oral antibiotics, laser therapy, and lifestyle changes to avoid triggers.

A skull fracture is a break in one of the cranial bones. Symptoms include head pain, swelling, bruising, bleeding from the ears or nose, and neurological symptoms. Treatment depends on severity and may involve observation, medications, or surgery.

Uveitis is inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye. Symptoms include eye pain, redness, blurred vision, and light sensitivity. Treatment includes corticosteroid eye drops, immunosuppressants, and treatment of underlying conditions.

A facial fracture involves broken bones of the face, such as the nose, jaw, or cheekbone. Symptoms include swelling, bruising, deformity, and difficulty breathing or chewing. Treatment includes pain management, realignment of bones, and sometimes surgical repair.

Tracheitis is inflammation or infection of the trachea, often bacterial. Symptoms include cough, fever, difficulty breathing, and stridor. It is more common in children. Treatment includes antibiotics, supportive care, and sometimes hospitalization for airway management.

Jaw disorders often refer to temporomandibular joint disorders (TMJ), affecting jaw movement. Symptoms include jaw pain, clicking sounds, headaches, and difficulty chewing. Treatment includes pain relief, mouth guards, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.
A perirectal infection is an abscess near the anus or rectum. Symptoms include rectal pain, swelling, redness, and sometimes fever. Treatment involves drainage of the abscess and antibiotics.

Breast cysts are fluid-filled sacs within the breast, often benign. Symptoms include a round, movable lump, tenderness, and changes related to the menstrual cycle. Treatment may include monitoring, aspiration of the fluid, or surgical removal if necessary.

PTSD is a mental health condition triggered by experiencing or witnessing trauma. Symptoms include flashbacks, nightmares, anxiety, and avoidance of reminders of the trauma. Treatment includes psychotherapy (especially CBT), EMDR, and medications like SSRIs.

Kidney cancer originates in the kidneys, commonly renal cell carcinoma. Symptoms include blood in urine, flank pain, weight loss, and fatigue. Treatment includes surgery (nephrectomy), targeted therapy, immunotherapy, and occasionally radiation.

Vulvar cancer is a rare cancer affecting the external female genitalia. Symptoms include itching, pain, lumps, and bleeding. Treatment includes surgical removal, radiation, and chemotherapy depending on stage and spread.

Blepharitis is inflammation of the eyelid margins. Symptoms include red, swollen eyelids, crusting, itching, and a gritty eye sensation. Treatment includes warm compresses, eyelid scrubs, antibiotic ointments, and managing underlying conditions like dandruff or rosacea.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, weight loss, fatigue, and anemia. Treatment involves a strict lifelong gluten-free diet.

Cystitis is inflammation of the bladder, commonly due to a urinary tract infection. Symptoms include frequent and painful urination, urgency, and lower abdominal pain. Treatment includes antibiotics, hydration, and pain relievers.

Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder causing red blood cells to assume a sickle shape, leading to blockages in blood flow. Symptoms include pain crises, anemia, fatigue, and increased risk of infections. Treatment includes pain management, blood transfusions, and medications like hydroxyurea.

Subconjunctival hemorrhage is bleeding under the conjunctiva of the eye, usually harmless. Symptoms include a red patch on the white of the eye without pain or vision changes. Treatment is typically not needed; the condition resolves on its own in 1–2 weeks.

Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the rectum or anus, causing pain, itching, and rectal bleeding. They may be internal or external. Treatment includes dietary fiber, topical creams, warm baths, and in severe cases, procedures like rubber band ligation or surgery.

Contact dermatitis is a skin rash caused by contact with an allergen or irritant. Symptoms include redness, itching, blisters, and dry patches. Treatment involves avoiding the trigger, using corticosteroid creams, and moisturizing the skin.

Sinus bradycardia is a slower-than-normal heart rate originating from the sinus node. It may be normal in athletes but can cause fatigue, dizziness, or fainting in others. Treatment is only necessary if symptomatic and may include medication adjustment or a pacemaker.

High blood pressure (hypertension) is a chronic condition where blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated. Symptoms are often absent but may include headaches or nosebleeds in severe cases. Treatment includes lifestyle changes and medications like ACE inhibitors or beta-blockers.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection of the female reproductive organs. Symptoms include pelvic pain, abnormal vaginal discharge, fever, and pain during sex. Treatment includes antibiotics and, in severe cases, hospitalization or surgery.

Liver disease encompasses a range of conditions affecting liver function, including hepatitis, fatty liver, and cirrhosis. Symptoms may include jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, and swelling. Treatment depends on the cause and may include medications, lifestyle changes, and in some cases, liver transplantation.

Chronic constipation is persistent difficulty in bowel movements. Symptoms include infrequent stools, straining, bloating, and a feeling of incomplete evacuation. Treatment includes dietary fiber, fluids, laxatives, and in some cases, prescription medications or biofeedback therapy.

Thyroid cancer is a malignancy of the thyroid gland. Symptoms may include a neck lump, hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and swollen lymph nodes. Treatment includes surgery, radioactive iodine, and thyroid hormone therapy.

Flu (influenza) is a viral respiratory illness. Symptoms include fever, chills, sore throat, cough, muscle aches, and fatigue. Treatment includes rest, hydration, antiviral medications (like oseltamivir), and symptom relief medications.

Friedrich ataxia is a rare genetic disorder that causes progressive damage to the nervous system. Symptoms include gait instability, muscle weakness, heart disease, and scoliosis. There is no cure; treatment focuses on managing symptoms with physical therapy and cardiac care.

Tic disorders involve sudden, repetitive movements or sounds. Symptoms include blinking, throat clearing, or other motor or vocal tics. Treatment includes behavioral therapy, medications like antipsychotics, and sometimes relaxation techniques.

Skin polyps, also known as skin tags, are benign, soft skin growths. They are typically asymptomatic but may cause irritation if rubbed. Treatment includes removal through cutting, freezing (cryotherapy), or cauterization if desired.

Brachial neuritis is inflammation of the brachial plexus nerves, causing sudden shoulder pain followed by weakness or numbness. Treatment includes pain management with NSAIDs, corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

Cervical cancer arises from the cervix, often linked to HPV infection. Symptoms include abnormal bleeding, pelvic pain, and discharge. Treatment involves surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy depending on the stage.

Adrenal adenoma is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland, sometimes producing excess hormones. Symptoms depend on hormone type and may include high blood pressure, weight gain, or fatigue. Treatment includes monitoring or surgical removal if hormone-secreting.

Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, often due to acid reflux, infections, or medications. Symptoms include heartburn, painful swallowing, and chest pain. Treatment includes proton pump inhibitors, dietary changes, and treating underlying causes.

Gas gangrene is a severe bacterial infection caused by Clostridium species, leading to tissue death and gas production in muscles. Symptoms include sudden pain, swelling, skin discoloration, and foul-smelling discharge. Treatment involves emergency surgery to remove dead tissue, antibiotics, and sometimes hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

A yeast infection is typically caused by Candida overgrowth, affecting moist areas like the mouth, skin folds, or vagina. Symptoms include itching, burning, redness, and white discharge. Treatment includes antifungal creams or oral medications like fluconazole.

Spina bifida is a birth defect where the spinal cord doesn’t develop properly. Symptoms vary by type but may include back protrusion, weakness, and bladder or bowel issues. Treatment includes surgery, physical therapy, and assistive devices.

Drug poisoning occurs from the ingestion of harmful doses of medication, whether accidental or intentional. Symptoms can include confusion, nausea, slowed breathing, and unconsciousness. Treatment involves activated charcoal, antidotes, and supportive care in a hospital.

Alcoholic liver disease is liver damage caused by excessive alcohol consumption. Symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, and swelling. Treatment involves complete cessation of alcohol, nutritional support, and medications to reduce inflammation.

Malignant hypertension is a severe form of high blood pressure that damages organs rapidly. Symptoms include headache, vision changes, chest pain, and confusion. It requires emergency treatment with intravenous antihypertensives and hospitalization.

Diverticulitis is inflammation or infection of diverticula in the colon. Symptoms include abdominal pain (usually on the lower left), fever, and changes in bowel habits. Treatment includes antibiotics, dietary modifications, and in severe cases, surgery.

Moyamoya disease is a rare condition where arteries at the base of the brain become narrowed, reducing blood flow. Symptoms include strokes, seizures, and cognitive issues. Treatment includes revascularization surgery and medications to prevent clots.

Heat exhaustion is caused by excessive heat and dehydration. Symptoms include heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, nausea, and fainting. Treatment includes moving to a cool area, hydration with water or electrolytes, and rest.

Psychotic disorders involve a disconnection from reality, such as hallucinations or delusions. Symptoms may include disorganized thinking, paranoia, and lack of insight. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications and psychotherapy.

Frostbite is damage to skin and tissues caused by freezing temperatures. Symptoms include numbness, skin discoloration, and blistering. Treatment involves gradual rewarming, wound care, and in severe cases, surgery or amputation.

Atrophy of the corpus cavernosum involves shrinkage of the erectile tissue in the penis, often due to lack of use, injury, or hormonal changes. Symptoms include erectile dysfunction and reduced penile size. Treatment includes testosterone therapy, vacuum erection devices, or penile implants.

Smoking addiction is a dependence on nicotine found in tobacco. Symptoms include cravings, irritability when not smoking, and compulsive use. Treatment includes nicotine replacement therapy, prescription medications like varenicline, and behavioral therapy.

A sprain is an injury to ligaments, and a strain is an injury to muscles or tendons. Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and limited motion. Treatment includes RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation), pain relievers, and physical therapy.

Essential tremor is a neurological condition causing rhythmic shaking, especially in the hands. Symptoms worsen with movement or stress. Treatment includes beta-blockers, anticonvulsants, and in severe cases, deep brain stimulation.

An open wound of the ear can result from trauma or surgery. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and possible hearing changes. Treatment involves cleaning the wound, antibiotics if infected, and suturing if deep.

Foreign bodies in the nose are common in children and can cause nasal obstruction, discharge, and foul odor. Treatment involves careful removal using instruments, sometimes under sedation or anesthesia.

Idiopathic painful menstruation (primary dysmenorrhea) involves painful periods without an underlying condition. Symptoms include cramping in the lower abdomen, nausea, and fatigue. Treatment includes NSAIDs, hormonal birth control, and heat therapy.

Down syndrome is a genetic condition caused by an extra chromosome 21. Symptoms include intellectual disability, distinct facial features, and developmental delays. Treatment includes early intervention programs, educational support, and medical monitoring.

Idiopathic infrequent menstruation (oligomenorrhea) refers to irregular periods without a known cause. Symptoms include long cycles or missed periods. Treatment depends on the patient’s goals and may include hormonal therapy or lifestyle adjustments.

Pneumothorax is the presence of air in the pleural space causing lung collapse. Symptoms include sudden chest pain, shortness of breath, and rapid heart rate. Treatment may involve observation for small cases, needle aspiration, chest tube insertion, or surgery in recurrent cases.

De Quervain disease is inflammation of the tendons in the thumb side of the wrist. Symptoms include wrist pain and swelling near the base of the thumb, especially with movement. Treatment includes splinting, NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, and sometimes surgery.

A vertebral fracture occurs when one or more spinal bones break due to trauma or osteoporosis. Symptoms include back pain, loss of height, or deformity. Treatment ranges from pain control and bracing to surgical procedures like vertebroplasty or spinal fusion.

HIV is a virus that attacks the immune system, increasing vulnerability to infections. Early symptoms include flu-like illness, while late stages lead to AIDS. Treatment involves lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) to control viral load and prevent progression.

Mumps is a viral infection affecting the salivary glands. Symptoms include swollen, painful parotid glands, fever, headache, and fatigue. Treatment is supportive—rest, hydration, and pain relievers. Vaccination (MMR) is effective for prevention.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding in the space between the brain and surrounding membrane, often due to a ruptured aneurysm. Symptoms include a sudden severe headache, neck stiffness, and loss of consciousness. Treatment involves emergency surgery or coiling, and ICU care.

AFLP is a rare but serious complication in pregnancy where fat accumulates in the liver. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, and confusion. Immediate delivery of the baby and intensive supportive care for the mother are essential.

Ectropion is the outward turning of the eyelid, usually the lower one, leading to exposure of the inner eyelid. Symptoms include irritation, tearing, and redness. Treatment includes lubricating eye drops, ointments, or surgical correction if severe.

A scar is fibrous tissue that replaces normal skin after injury. Symptoms may include discoloration, raised or sunken appearance, or itchiness. Treatment includes topical creams, silicone sheets, laser therapy, or surgical revision depending on severity.

Lactose intolerance is the inability to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk. Symptoms include bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps after dairy consumption. Treatment includes avoiding lactose-containing foods or using lactase enzyme supplements.

Eustachian tube dysfunction occurs when the tubes connecting the middle ear to the throat fail to open properly. Symptoms include ear fullness, popping, hearing loss, and discomfort. Treatment includes decongestants, nasal steroids, and in chronic cases, tube placement.

Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix, usually due to obstruction. Symptoms include sharp abdominal pain starting near the navel, then shifting to the lower right abdomen, along with nausea and fever. Treatment is usually surgical removal (appendectomy).

Graves disease is an autoimmune condition causing hyperthyroidism. Symptoms include weight loss, rapid heartbeat, heat intolerance, and bulging eyes. Treatment includes antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine therapy, or surgery to remove the thyroid.

Dissociative disorders involve disconnection from thoughts, identity, or surroundings, often due to trauma. Symptoms include memory loss, identity confusion, or feeling detached from reality. Treatment includes psychotherapy, particularly cognitive behavioral and trauma-focused therapies.

An open wound of the face can result from trauma, accidents, or surgery. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and visible skin breakage. Treatment involves cleaning, suturing if needed, antibiotics, and wound care to prevent infection and minimize scarring.

Vertebral dislocation occurs when vertebrae are displaced due to trauma. Symptoms include severe back pain, nerve symptoms like numbness, and spinal instability. Treatment includes spinal immobilization, realignment (reduction), and possibly surgical stabilization.

Phimosis is a condition where the foreskin cannot be fully retracted over the glans penis. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, or infection. Treatment includes topical steroids, stretching exercises, or circumcision if recurrent problems occur.

Hyperemesis gravidarum is severe nausea and vomiting in pregnancy that leads to weight loss and dehydration. Symptoms include persistent vomiting, electrolyte imbalance, and fatigue. Treatment includes IV fluids, antiemetics, and sometimes hospitalization.

Pregnancy is the condition of carrying a developing fetus in the uterus. Symptoms include missed periods, nausea, breast tenderness, and fatigue. Regular prenatal care, balanced diet, and avoiding harmful substances are key aspects of management.

Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder that reduces hemoglobin production. Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, pale skin, and enlarged spleen. Treatment includes regular blood transfusions, iron chelation therapy, and bone marrow transplant in severe cases.

Placenta previa occurs when the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix during pregnancy. Symptoms include painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester. Treatment involves monitoring, bed rest, and cesarean delivery depending on severity and gestational age.

Epidural hemorrhage is bleeding between the skull and the outer membrane covering the brain, usually caused by trauma. Symptoms include brief loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval and then rapid deterioration. Emergency surgical intervention is usually required.

Septic arthritis is a joint infection caused by bacteria or other organisms. Symptoms include sudden joint pain, swelling, redness, and fever. Treatment involves urgent drainage of the joint and intravenous antibiotics.

Athlete's foot is a fungal infection that affects the skin on the feet, especially between the toes. Symptoms include itching, peeling, and redness. Treatment includes antifungal creams, keeping the feet dry, and avoiding contaminated surfaces.

Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space around the lungs. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough. Treatment depends on the cause and may involve draining the fluid and treating underlying conditions such as infection or cancer.

Aphakia refers to the absence of the lens in the eye, usually due to surgical removal for cataracts. Symptoms include blurred vision, focusing difficulties, and glare. Treatment involves corrective lenses, contact lenses, or intraocular lens implants.

Vulvar disorders encompass various conditions affecting the external female genitalia. Symptoms may include itching, burning, pain, or skin changes. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antifungals, corticosteroids, or surgery for more serious issues.

Sialoadenitis is inflammation of a salivary gland, often due to bacterial infection. Symptoms include pain, swelling near the jaw, fever, and dry mouth. Treatment includes antibiotics, hydration, massage, and warm compresses.

Gynecomastia is the benign enlargement of male breast tissue, often due to hormonal imbalance, medications, or liver disease. Symptoms include swollen breast gland tissue and tenderness. Treatment may involve observation, medications, or surgery if persistent.

Urinary tract infection (UTI) is a bacterial infection affecting any part of the urinary system. Symptoms include frequent urination, burning sensation, and cloudy or bloody urine. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and increased fluid intake.

Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by inhaling spores from bird or bat droppings. Symptoms range from mild respiratory illness to severe systemic infection. Treatment involves antifungal medications like itraconazole or amphotericin B.

Erythema multiforme is an immune-mediated skin reaction often triggered by infections or medications. Symptoms include red target-like lesions on the skin and sometimes mucosal involvement. Treatment is supportive, including antihistamines and corticosteroids in severe cases.

Scoliosis is a sideways curvature of the spine that usually develops during childhood or adolescence. Symptoms may include uneven shoulders, back pain, and visible spinal curvature. Treatment includes observation, bracing, or surgery in severe cases.

A bunion is a bony bump that forms on the joint at the base of the big toe. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity. Treatment includes wearing proper footwear, orthotics, pain relievers, and surgery if conservative measures fail.

Arrhythmia is an irregular heartbeat that can be too fast, too slow, or erratic. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, fatigue, or fainting. Treatment includes medications, pacemakers, ablation therapy, or lifestyle changes depending on the type and severity.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a chronic pain condition affecting the trigeminal nerve in the face. Symptoms include sudden, severe facial pain triggered by mild stimulation. Treatment involves medications like anticonvulsants or surgical procedures to relieve nerve pressure.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of arthritis that primarily affects the spine, causing inflammation, pain, and stiffness. Symptoms often begin in early adulthood and may lead to spinal fusion. Treatment includes NSAIDs, physical therapy, and biologic medications.

Peripheral nerve disorders involve damage to the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include tingling, numbness, weakness, and pain. Treatment depends on the cause and may include medications, physical therapy, or surgery.

A sebaceous cyst is a noncancerous, closed sac under the skin filled with a greasy substance. Symptoms include a lump under the skin, which may become red or painful if infected. Treatment includes drainage or surgical removal if bothersome.

Poisoning due to antipsychotics occurs from overdose or side effects of medications used to treat mental disorders. Symptoms include drowsiness, low blood pressure, tremors, and potentially seizures or coma. Treatment involves supportive care, gastric decontamination, and monitoring in a medical facility.

Neurosis refers to a group of mental health conditions involving chronic distress but not delusions or hallucinations. Symptoms include anxiety, depression, obsessive thoughts, or phobias. Treatment typically includes psychotherapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and sometimes medications like antidepressants.

Prostate cancer is a malignancy in the prostate gland, common in older men. Symptoms may include difficulty urinating, blood in urine, and pelvic discomfort. Treatments include surgery, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, and active surveillance for low-risk cases.

Cerebral edema is swelling of the brain caused by trauma, stroke, infection, or tumors. Symptoms include headache, confusion, seizures, and loss of consciousness. Treatment includes osmotic agents like mannitol, corticosteroids, and addressing the underlying cause.

A dislocation of the finger occurs when bones in a finger joint are forced out of place. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity of the finger. Treatment involves manual reduction, splinting, and sometimes surgery in severe cases.

Birth trauma refers to injuries sustained by a newborn during delivery. Symptoms vary by type and may include bruising, fractures, or nerve damage. Treatment depends on the injury and can range from observation to surgical repair.

Chronic pancreatitis is long-term inflammation of the pancreas, often due to alcohol abuse. Symptoms include abdominal pain, weight loss, and malabsorption. Treatment involves pain management, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and avoiding alcohol.

A hematoma is a localized collection of blood outside blood vessels, usually due to injury. Symptoms include swelling, discoloration, and tenderness. Treatment may include rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE), and drainage if large or painful.

Carcinoid syndrome is a group of symptoms caused by hormone-secreting tumors, typically in the digestive tract. Symptoms include flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing. Treatment involves surgical removal, somatostatin analogs, and managing hormone levels.

An open wound of the head is a break in the skin or scalp often caused by trauma. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and visible tissue damage. Treatment includes cleaning, suturing, antibiotics if needed, and monitoring for concussion or skull injury.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin growth that appears as a waxy, scaly, slightly elevated lesion. Symptoms are usually cosmetic, with no discomfort. Treatment is not necessary unless removal is desired for cosmetic reasons or irritation.

A burn is tissue damage caused by heat, chemicals, electricity, or radiation. Symptoms vary by severity and include redness, blistering, and charring. Treatment ranges from cool compresses and dressings to fluid resuscitation and skin grafts for severe burns.

Spontaneous abortion, or miscarriage, is the loss of a pregnancy before 20 weeks. Symptoms include vaginal bleeding, cramping, and loss of pregnancy symptoms. Treatment includes observation, medications to complete the miscarriage, or surgical removal (D&C).

Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus. Symptoms include painful blisters, ulcers, itching, and flu-like symptoms. Treatment includes antiviral medications like acyclovir to manage outbreaks.

Adjustment reaction is a psychological response to a stressor, resulting in emotional or behavioral symptoms. Symptoms include sadness, anxiety, or disturbances in daily function. Treatment involves psychotherapy, support, and sometimes medications for mood symptoms.

Gallstones are hardened deposits of bile that form in the gallbladder. Symptoms include right upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment includes dietary changes, medications, or surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy).

Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system. Symptoms include fatigue, numbness, vision problems, and motor impairment. Treatment includes disease-modifying therapies, steroids, and supportive rehabilitation.

Zenker diverticulum is a pouch that forms in the upper esophagus causing swallowing difficulties. Symptoms include dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and chronic cough. Treatment involves dietary modifications and surgical correction in severe cases.

A fracture of the pelvis can result from trauma or falls. Symptoms include pelvic pain, difficulty walking, and bruising. Treatment may include bed rest, pain management, and surgery for unstable fractures.

Pneumoconiosis is a lung disease caused by inhalation of dust, especially in occupational settings. Symptoms include chronic cough, shortness of breath, and chest tightness. Treatment involves removing exposure, supportive care, and managing complications.

Hyperlipidemia is a condition characterized by elevated levels of lipids in the blood, such as cholesterol and triglycerides. Symptoms are usually absent but increase cardiovascular risk. Treatment includes diet changes, exercise, and medications like statins.

Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that affects the colon and rectum. Symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea with blood, fatigue, and weight loss. Treatment involves anti-inflammatory drugs like aminosalicylates, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and sometimes surgery to remove the colon.

Male genitalia infections can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi and may affect the penis, scrotum, or urethra. Symptoms include redness, swelling, discharge, itching, and pain. Treatment depends on the cause and may include antibiotics, antifungals, antivirals, and hygiene measures.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a common sexually transmitted infection. Symptoms may include genital warts, but many cases are asymptomatic. Certain strains can cause cervical and other cancers. Treatment includes topical medications or surgical removal of warts and vaccines for prevention.

Angina is chest pain or discomfort due to reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. Symptoms include pressure or squeezing in the chest, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment involves lifestyle changes, medications like nitrates and beta-blockers, and possibly angioplasty or surgery.

Spinal cord injury involves damage to the spinal cord that results in loss of function, such as mobility or sensation. Symptoms depend on the level and severity of the injury. Treatment focuses on emergency care, rehabilitation, and managing long-term complications.

Nasal polyps are noncancerous growths in the nasal passages or sinuses. Symptoms include nasal congestion, loss of smell, sinus pressure, and frequent infections. Treatment includes nasal corticosteroids, antihistamines, or surgical removal.

Lichen simplex chronicus is a skin disorder characterized by thickened, itchy patches of skin from chronic scratching. Symptoms include leathery skin plaques and intense itching. Treatment includes topical steroids, antihistamines, and behavior modification to stop scratching.

Trichiasis is a condition where eyelashes grow inward toward the eye, irritating the cornea. Symptoms include eye pain, redness, tearing, and sensitivity to light. Treatment includes removing the misdirected lashes, electrolysis, or surgery.

Acariasis is an infestation caused by mites, such as scabies or other skin-burrowing mites. Symptoms include intense itching, skin rash, and redness. Treatment includes topical or oral antiparasitic medications like permethrin or ivermectin.

Colorectal cancer is cancer of the colon or rectum. Symptoms include blood in stool, changes in bowel habits, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapies.

Skin pigmentation disorders include conditions like vitiligo, melasma, or hyperpigmentation. Symptoms involve patches of lighter or darker skin. Treatments depend on the type and may include topical creams, laser therapy, and sun protection.

Factitious disorder is a mental illness where a person deliberately produces or exaggerates symptoms of illness. Symptoms can vary widely and are self-induced. Treatment involves psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy, and addressing underlying psychological issues.

Lymphogranuloma venereum is a sexually transmitted infection caused by certain strains of Chlamydia trachomatis. Symptoms include genital ulcers, swollen lymph nodes, and rectal pain. Treatment involves a prolonged course of antibiotics like doxycycline.

Galactorrhea is the spontaneous flow of milk from the breast unrelated to childbirth or nursing. Symptoms include milky nipple discharge and possible menstrual irregularities. Treatment involves identifying and addressing underlying causes, or using medications to reduce prolactin levels if idiopathic.

G6PD deficiency is a genetic disorder that causes red blood cells to break down under certain stressors. Symptoms include fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine, especially after certain foods or medications. Treatment involves avoiding triggers and supportive care during hemolytic episodes.

Nerve impingement near the shoulder often involves compression of the brachial plexus or peripheral nerves. Symptoms include shoulder pain, weakness, tingling, and numbness. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medications, and sometimes surgery.

Toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the Toxoplasma gondii parasite, often contracted through undercooked meat or exposure to cat feces. Symptoms may include flu-like signs such as swollen lymph nodes, muscle aches, and fatigue, though it may be asymptomatic in healthy individuals. In pregnant women or immunocompromised people, it can cause serious complications like brain inflammation or fetal damage. Treatment typically involves medications such as pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine along with folinic acid.

Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor commonly found in young women. It feels like a firm, smooth, and movable lump in the breast, usually painless. These tumors often do not require treatment unless they grow, cause discomfort, or raise concern, in which case surgical removal may be recommended. Monitoring through regular exams or imaging is often sufficient.

An open wound of the hand refers to a break in the skin due to cuts, abrasions, punctures, or lacerations. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, swelling, and risk of infection. Treatment involves cleaning the wound, stopping the bleeding, applying antibiotics, and dressing it properly. Severe wounds may require stitches or surgical intervention.

Missed abortion (missed miscarriage) occurs when a fetus dies or fails to develop but is not expelled from the uterus. Symptoms are often absent, but may include loss of pregnancy symptoms or brownish discharge. Diagnosis is made via ultrasound. Treatment options include waiting for natural expulsion, medication to induce miscarriage, or a surgical procedure called dilation and curettage (D&C).

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a life-threatening complication of diabetes, typically type 1, where the body breaks down fat too quickly, producing ketones that make the blood acidic. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, rapid breathing, fruity-smelling breath, confusion, and dehydration. Treatment involves intravenous insulin, fluids, and electrolyte replacement to stabilize the patient.

Granuloma inguinale is a sexually transmitted bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It causes painless genital ulcers that progressively enlarge and bleed easily. If untreated, it can lead to tissue destruction. Treatment involves antibiotics, typically doxycycline, taken for several weeks until all lesions heal.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder is a mental health condition characterized by intrusive, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) performed to reduce anxiety. Common symptoms include excessive cleaning, checking, or counting. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), especially exposure and response prevention (ERP), and medications like SSRIs.

An ankle injury typically involves a sprain, strain, or fracture due to trauma or twisting. Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty walking. Treatment depends on severity and may involve rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE), immobilization, physical therapy, or surgery in severe cases.

Hyponatremia is a condition where blood sodium levels are abnormally low, leading to water imbalance in cells. Symptoms range from nausea and headache to confusion, seizures, and coma in severe cases. Treatment includes fluid restriction, salt tablets, or intravenous sodium, depending on the underlying cause and severity.

Esophageal stricture refers to a narrowing of the esophagus that causes difficulty swallowing. It can result from chronic acid reflux, injury, or radiation. Symptoms include trouble swallowing, food getting stuck, and chest discomfort. Treatment often includes esophageal dilation and addressing the underlying cause, such as acid suppression with medications.

An ankle fracture is a break in one or more of the bones that form the ankle joint, typically due to trauma. Symptoms include severe pain, swelling, bruising, and inability to bear weight. Treatment may involve immobilization with a cast or splint, and in severe cases, surgical fixation with plates or screws.

Soft tissue sarcoma is a rare cancer that arises from connective tissues like fat, muscle, or blood vessels. It often presents as a painless lump that grows over time. Symptoms depend on location and size. Treatment typically includes surgery, radiation, and sometimes chemotherapy, depending on the type and stage.

Bone disorders refer to conditions affecting the strength, structure, or formation of bones, such as osteoporosis, osteogenesis imperfecta, or Paget's disease. Symptoms vary but may include pain, fractures, deformities, or mobility issues. Treatment depends on the specific disorder and may involve medications, supplements, physical therapy, or surgery.

Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures due to abnormal brain activity. Symptoms vary by seizure type and may include convulsions, loss of consciousness, or brief staring spells. Treatment involves anti-epileptic drugs, lifestyle adjustments, and in some cases, surgery or neurostimulation devices.

Personality disorders are mental health conditions involving enduring, inflexible patterns of thinking and behavior that impair social and occupational functioning. Examples include borderline, narcissistic, and antisocial personality disorders. Treatment typically involves psychotherapy, especially cognitive behavioral therapy, and sometimes medication for co-occurring symptoms like depression or anxiety.

Shingles is caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, leading to a painful, blistering rash typically on one side of the body. Symptoms also include burning or tingling pain, fever, and fatigue. Treatment includes antiviral medications (like acyclovir), pain relievers, and sometimes corticosteroids.

Tourette syndrome is a neurological disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements and vocalizations called tics. Symptoms often begin in childhood and may include blinking, head jerking, or vocal sounds. Treatment includes behavioral therapy and, in some cases, medications like antipsychotics or alpha agonists.

Avascular necrosis is the death of bone tissue due to reduced blood flow, often affecting the hip. Symptoms include joint pain and stiffness that worsen over time. Causes include trauma, steroid use, or alcohol abuse. Treatment includes rest, medications, physical therapy, and possibly surgical procedures like joint replacement.

Strep throat is a bacterial infection of the throat caused by group A Streptococcus. Symptoms include sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and red tonsils with white patches. It is treated with antibiotics, typically penicillin or amoxicillin, and supportive care like pain relievers and fluids.

Spinocerebellar ataxia is a group of inherited disorders that cause progressive coordination and balance problems due to degeneration of the cerebellum and spinal cord. Symptoms include unsteady gait, speech difficulties, and fine motor issues. There is no cure; treatment focuses on symptom management through physical therapy and supportive care.

Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone, usually caused by bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus. Symptoms include bone pain, swelling, redness, and fever. Diagnosis often involves imaging and biopsy. Treatment includes prolonged antibiotic therapy and sometimes surgical removal of infected bone tissue.

Sjögren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth due to immune attack on moisture-producing glands. Other symptoms include joint pain and fatigue. Treatment includes artificial tears, saliva stimulants, and immunosuppressive medications for systemic symptoms.

Also known as frozen shoulder, this condition involves stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint due to inflammation and thickening of the joint capsule. Symptoms progress through stages of pain and increasing immobility. Treatment includes physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medications, and sometimes corticosteroid injections or surgery.

Viral hepatitis is liver inflammation caused by viruses such as hepatitis A, B, or C. Symptoms may include fatigue, jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea, and dark urine. Treatment depends on the type—supportive care for hepatitis A, antiviral therapy for hepatitis B and C, and monitoring for liver damage.

Tonsillar hypertrophy refers to the abnormal enlargement of the tonsils, often due to chronic infections or inflammation. Symptoms include snoring, difficulty swallowing, mouth breathing, and sleep apnea. Treatment depends on severity and may include observation, antibiotics, or tonsillectomy if causing obstruction or recurrent infections.

Gastritis is the inflammation of the stomach lining, often caused by infection with H. pylori, prolonged NSAID use, alcohol, or stress. Symptoms include stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, and bloating. Treatment involves antacids, proton pump inhibitors, antibiotics for H. pylori, and avoiding irritants.

Skin cancer is the uncontrolled growth of abnormal skin cells, including types like basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma. Symptoms may include a new mole, skin lesion, or sore that doesn’t heal. Treatment depends on the type and may involve surgical removal, topical treatments, radiation, or immunotherapy.

Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that can develop after untreated or poorly treated strep throat. It affects the heart, joints, skin, and brain. Symptoms include fever, joint pain, rash, and heart murmur. Treatment includes antibiotics, anti-inflammatory medications, and long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrence.

Aphthous ulcers, also known as canker sores, are small, painful lesions inside the mouth. They are not contagious and often triggered by stress, minor injury, or certain foods. Symptoms include round or oval ulcers with a white or yellow center. Treatment includes topical pastes, mouth rinses, and pain relievers.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils, typically due to viral or bacterial infection. Symptoms include sore throat, difficulty swallowing, swollen lymph nodes, fever, and red or white patches on the tonsils. Treatment involves rest, fluids, pain relievers, and antibiotics if bacterial. Recurrent cases may require tonsillectomy.

Intestinal cancer includes malignancies of the small or large intestine, such as colorectal cancer. Symptoms include abdominal pain, blood in stool, changes in bowel habits, and unexplained weight loss. Treatment typically involves surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, or targeted therapy depending on the cancer type and stage.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a bacterial infection transmitted by tick bites. Symptoms include fever, headache, rash, nausea, and muscle pain. It can be life-threatening if not treated promptly. Doxycycline is the first-line treatment, even in children, and should be started as soon as the disease is suspected.

Stomach cancer, or gastric cancer, often develops slowly and may go unnoticed in early stages. Symptoms include indigestion, bloating, nausea, weight loss, and blood in stool. Treatment may involve surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and targeted drug therapy depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

Developmental disabilities are a group of conditions due to impairments in physical, learning, language, or behavior areas. They may include autism, cerebral palsy, and intellectual disabilities. Symptoms vary widely. There is no cure, but early intervention, special education, and therapies can help improve quality of life.

Acute stress reaction is a psychological response to a traumatic or stressful event. Symptoms include anxiety, confusion, irritability, insomnia, and physical complaints like heart palpitations. It typically resolves on its own, but supportive therapy and short-term medications like anxiolytics may be used.

Delirium is a sudden change in mental status marked by confusion, disorientation, and difficulty concentrating. It is often caused by illness, medications, or substance withdrawal. Treatment involves identifying and correcting the underlying cause and providing supportive care and a calm environment.

A callus is a thickened area of skin that forms due to repeated friction or pressure, often on hands or feet. Symptoms include hardened, rough skin and sometimes pain. Treatment includes removing the source of friction, moisturizing, and using pumice stones or protective pads.

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis. Symptoms start with tingling in the legs and can progress to complete paralysis. Treatment includes intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

Lumbago is lower back pain that can result from muscle strain, spinal issues, or poor posture. Symptoms include localized back pain and stiffness. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medications, and in some cases, heat or cold therapy or chiropractic care.

A deviated septum occurs when the nasal septum is displaced to one side, possibly causing breathing difficulty, nasal congestion, and frequent sinus infections. Treatment includes medications like decongestants and nasal sprays, and in more severe cases, surgical correction (septoplasty).

A hemangioma is a benign tumor of blood vessels, often appearing as a red or purple birthmark in infants. Symptoms depend on location and size. Most resolve on their own, but treatment may involve beta-blockers like propranolol, laser therapy, or surgical removal if causing complications.

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a condition where narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs, often due to atherosclerosis. Symptoms include leg pain while walking (claudication), cold feet, and slow-healing wounds. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, medications, and in severe cases, angioplasty or surgery.

Chronic back pain is persistent pain in the back lasting more than 12 weeks. It may be due to injury, degenerative changes, or structural problems. Symptoms include constant or intermittent pain and reduced mobility. Treatment involves physical therapy, pain medications, injections, and sometimes surgery.

Heart failure is a condition where the heart cannot pump blood effectively to meet the body's needs. Symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, swelling in the legs, and rapid heartbeat. Treatment includes medications (like ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics), lifestyle changes, and sometimes devices or surgery.

Conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, is inflammation of the conjunctiva—the thin membrane covering the white part of the eye and inner eyelids. Symptoms include redness, itchiness, tearing, discharge, and a gritty feeling. Causes include viral or bacterial infections, allergens, or irritants. Treatment depends on the cause: antibiotics for bacterial cases, antihistamines for allergic reactions, and supportive care for viral infections.

A herniated disk occurs when the soft center of a spinal disk pushes through a crack in the tougher exterior. Symptoms include back pain, leg or arm pain, numbness, or weakness. Most cases improve with rest, physical therapy, and anti-inflammatory medications. Severe cases may require steroid injections or surgery.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious condition caused by muscle breakdown releasing myoglobin into the bloodstream, potentially damaging the kidneys. Symptoms include muscle pain, weakness, dark urine, and fatigue. Causes include trauma, overexertion, or drug use. Treatment involves IV fluids to flush toxins, and sometimes dialysis in severe cases.

Mastitis is an infection of breast tissue, common in breastfeeding women. Symptoms include breast pain, swelling, redness, warmth, fever, and flu-like symptoms. It’s usually caused by bacteria entering through a cracked nipple. Treatment includes antibiotics, pain relief, and continued breastfeeding or pumping to clear the infection.

An abdominal aortic aneurysm is a bulge in the wall of the aorta as it passes through the abdomen. It may be asymptomatic or cause deep, constant pain in the abdomen or back. If it ruptures, it causes life-threatening internal bleeding. Treatment involves monitoring small aneurysms and surgical repair for larger or symptomatic ones.

A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, often caused by blood clots from the legs (deep vein thrombosis). Symptoms include sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, cough, and rapid heartbeat. Treatment includes blood thinners, clot-dissolving medications, and sometimes surgery.

Conduct disorder is a behavioral disorder in children and teens involving aggressive, disruptive, or antisocial behavior. Symptoms include violating rules, cruelty to animals, fighting, and theft. Causes are multifactorial, including genetics and environment. Treatment involves psychotherapy, behavioral interventions, family counseling, and sometimes medications.

A mastectomy is the surgical removal of one or both breasts, often to treat or prevent breast cancer. Recovery involves wound care, pain management, and emotional support. Complications may include infection or lymphedema. Follow-up may include reconstructive surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy depending on the underlying condition.

Epididymitis is inflammation of the epididymis, often caused by bacterial infection or sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia or gonorrhea. Symptoms include scrotal pain, swelling, redness, and fever. Treatment includes antibiotics, rest, scrotal elevation, and anti-inflammatory medications.

Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) refers to the breaking of the water (amniotic sac) before labor begins. It increases the risk of infection and preterm birth. Symptoms include a sudden gush or constant leak of fluid from the vagina. Management includes monitoring, antibiotics, and inducing labor if necessary.

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that causes small, painless, pearly bumps with a central dimple. It spreads via skin contact or contaminated objects. It’s usually self-limiting but can be treated with cryotherapy, curettage, or topical agents for quicker resolution or if spreading.

Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe bacterial infection that destroys tissue under the skin, often called flesh-eating disease. Symptoms include rapidly spreading redness, swelling, severe pain, and systemic signs like fever and shock. It requires emergency surgical removal of infected tissue, antibiotics, and intensive care.

Leukorrhea is a normal, benign vaginal discharge that is typically clear or white and odorless. It may increase due to hormonal changes, pregnancy, or ovulation. No treatment is needed unless it’s accompanied by odor, itching, or color change, which may suggest infection.

Bladder obstruction refers to blockage in the bladder outlet, which interferes with urine flow. Symptoms include difficulty urinating, weak stream, frequent urination, and incomplete emptying. Causes may include enlarged prostate, stones, or strictures. Treatment depends on the cause and may involve catheterization, surgery, or medication.

Melanoma is a serious form of skin cancer that originates in melanocytes. It can develop in existing moles or appear as a new dark spot. Symptoms include asymmetrical shape, irregular borders, varied color, and rapid growth. Treatment involves surgical removal, and in advanced stages, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or chemotherapy.

Cervical disorders encompass a range of issues affecting the cervix, including inflammation (cervicitis), cervical dysplasia, and cervical cancer. Symptoms may include abnormal vaginal bleeding, discharge, or pain during intercourse. Diagnosis may involve Pap smear or HPV testing. Treatment varies from antibiotics to surgery depending on the condition.

Laryngitis is inflammation of the larynx (voice box), often caused by infection or overuse of the voice. Symptoms include hoarseness, loss of voice, throat pain, and dry cough. Treatment involves resting the voice, hydration, humidifiers, and addressing any underlying infections or irritants.

Dyshidrosis is a skin condition causing small, itchy blisters on the hands and feet. It’s often triggered by stress, allergies, or moisture. Symptoms include intense itching, blisters, and skin peeling. Treatment involves corticosteroid creams, moisturizers, antihistamines, and avoiding irritants.

Opioid poisoning occurs when a person overdoses on opioids like morphine, heroin, or fentanyl. Symptoms include slowed or stopped breathing, unconsciousness, pinpoint pupils, and blue lips or nails. Emergency treatment includes administration of naloxone (Narcan), supportive care, and hospitalization.

Diaper rash is a common form of inflamed skin that appears as a red, tender area on a baby’s buttocks or genitals, often due to prolonged exposure to a wet diaper. Treatment includes frequent diaper changes, barrier creams like zinc oxide, and keeping the area clean and dry.

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the skin and mucous membranes. It presents as purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on the skin or white lacy patches in the mouth. Symptoms include itching, pain (especially in oral/genital forms), and skin discoloration. Treatment includes corticosteroids, antihistamines, and immunosuppressive agents for severe cases.

Gastroduodenal ulcers are open sores in the lining of the stomach or the first part of the small intestine (duodenum). They are often caused by H. pylori infection or prolonged NSAID use. Symptoms include burning abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Treatment involves proton pump inhibitors, antibiotics (for H. pylori), and avoiding NSAIDs.

An inguinal hernia occurs when tissue, such as part of the intestine, protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall near the groin. It appears as a bulge that may be painful, especially when bending or coughing. Surgery is the definitive treatment, either open or laparoscopic repair.

Eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy, red, and cracked skin. It can affect any part of the body and often flares with allergens, stress, or irritants. Treatment includes moisturizing creams, topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, and avoiding triggers.

Asperger syndrome is a developmental disorder on the autism spectrum, characterized by difficulty in social interactions and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior. Language and cognitive development are typically normal. Management includes behavioral therapy, social skills training, and support for co-occurring issues like anxiety.

Mucositis is inflammation and ulceration of the mucous membranes, commonly occurring as a side effect of chemotherapy or radiation therapy. Symptoms include mouth pain, redness, ulcers, and difficulty eating or swallowing. Treatment involves oral hygiene, pain management, mouth rinses, and nutritional support.

Paronychia is an infection of the skin around the nails, usually caused by bacteria or fungi. Symptoms include redness, swelling, tenderness, and pus near the nail. Acute cases are treated with warm soaks and antibiotics, while chronic or fungal cases may require antifungal medications.

An open wound of the jaw involves a break in the skin and underlying tissue due to trauma or surgery. Symptoms include bleeding, pain, and risk of infection. Treatment includes cleaning the wound, suturing if necessary, antibiotics, and monitoring for complications like infection or impaired jaw function.

White blood cell (WBC) diseases refer to disorders like leukemia or lymphoma that affect the production or function of WBCs. Symptoms vary but may include infections, fatigue, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Treatment depends on the specific disease and may include chemotherapy, radiation, or bone marrow transplant.

Kaposi sarcoma is a rare cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels, often associated with HIV/AIDS. It appears as red, purple, or brown skin lesions, and may affect internal organs. Treatment includes antiretroviral therapy (for HIV), radiation, chemotherapy, or targeted therapy depending on severity.

Spondylolisthesis is the forward slipping of one vertebra over the one below it, usually in the lower spine. Symptoms include lower back pain, stiffness, muscle tightness, and nerve symptoms like tingling or weakness. Treatment ranges from physical therapy and bracing to surgical spinal fusion in severe cases.

Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) is a condition with increased pressure around the brain without a tumor. Symptoms include headaches, vision problems, and ringing in the ears. It’s more common in overweight women. Treatment includes weight loss, diuretics, and in some cases, surgery to relieve pressure.

Viral conjunctivitis is an infection of the eye’s conjunctiva typically caused by adenovirus. It spreads easily and causes redness, watery discharge, and a gritty feeling in the eyes. It is self-limiting and usually resolves within 1–2 weeks. Treatment is supportive, including cool compresses and hygiene to prevent spread.

An open wound of the nose results from trauma or surgical intervention and involves damage to nasal skin and tissues. Symptoms include bleeding, swelling, pain, and risk of infection. Treatment includes wound cleaning, possible suturing, antibiotics if infected, and proper wound care to promote healing.
